questions.text: Streptococcus bovis infection is associated with:
questions.solution:
Colorectal cancer is strongly associated with Streptococcus bovis infection.

 Cancer  Organism causing infection related mortality
 Colon and rectal tumours  Streptococcus bovis 
 Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia  S. pneumonia, H. influenzae, N. meningitidis
 Multiple myeloma  Streptococcus pnuemoniae
 Hairy cell leukaemia

 Intracellular pathogens (M. tuberculosis, Listeria, Cryptococcus, M. avium)

Clinical significance: Colonoscopy is mandatory after Streptococcus bovis endocarditis.

questions.text:
Match the following delusions with associated syndrome:
Delusion Syndrome
i. Delusion of Love a. Capgras Syndrome
ii. Delusion of Misidentification b. De Clerambault syndrome
iii. Nihilistic Delusion c. Ekbom syndrome
iv. Delusion of infestation d. Cotard syndrome
  e. Othello syndrome
questions.solution:
Delusion and associated syndromes:

  • Delusion of love - De clerambault syndrome
  • Delusion of misidentification - Capgras syndrome
  • Nihilistic delusion - Cotard syndrome
  • Delusion of infestation - Ekbom syndrome

Delusion is a disorder of thought content and is defined as a false belief, based on incorrect inference about exter­nal reality, that is firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof or evidence and despite the fact that other members of the culture do not share the belief.

Note: Restless legs syndrome is also called as Willis-Ekbom disease (RLS/WED). It is a chronic neurosensory disorder that is characterized by a strong urge to move, accompanied by uncomfortable paresthesia in the legs which affects about 5-15 percent of adult people in industrialized countries. Should not be confused with Ekbom syndrome.

 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: Mycoplasma is intrinsically resistant to_____________
questions.solution:
Mycoplasma is intrinsically resistant to ceftriaxone (third generation cephalosporin).

In Mycoplasma, rigid cell wall (Peptidoglycan layer) is absent, which is replaced by cholesterol.

Hence they are resistant to cell wall active antibiotics like beta lactams. Cephalosporins exert bactericidal activity by interfering with bacterial cell wall synthesis and inhibiting cross-linking of the peptidoglycan. 

ORGANISMS

NATURAL RESISTANCE AGAINST:

MECHANISM

Anaerobic bacteria

Aminoglycosides

Lack of oxidative metabolism to drive uptake of aminoglycosides

Aerobic bacteria

Metronidazole

Inability to anaerobically reduce drug to its active form

Gram-positive bacteria

Aztreonam (a beta-lactam)

Lack of penicillin binding proteins (PBPs) that bind and are inhibited by this beta lactam antibiotic

Gram-negative bacteria

Vancomycin

Lack of uptake resulting from inability of vancomycin to penetrate outer membrane

Klebsiella spp.

Ampicillin (a beta-lactam)

Production of enzymes (beta-lactamases) that destroy ampicillin before the drug can reach the PBP targets

Stenotrophomonas. maltophila

Imipenem (a beta-lactam)

Production of enzymes (beta lactamases) that destroy imipenem before the drug can reach the PBP targets.

Lactobacilli and Leuconostoc

Vancomycin

Lack of appropriate cell wall precursor target to allow vancomycin to bind and inhibit cell wall synthesis

Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Sulfonamides, trimethoprim, tetracycline, or chloramphenicol

Lack of uptake resulting from inability of antibiotics to achieve effective intracellular concentrations

Enterococci

Aminoglycosides

Lack of sufficient oxidative metabolism to drive uptake of aminoglycosides

All cephalosporins

Lack of PBPs that effectively bind and are inhibited by these beta lactam antibiotics

 

Note:Intrinsic resistance is the innate ability of a bacterial species to resist activity of a particular antimicrobial agent through its inherent structural or functional characteristics, which allow tolerance of a particular drug or antimicrobial class.

Clinical implications: Intrinsic Resistance

Knowledge of the intrinsic resistance of a pathogen of concern is important in practice to avoid inappropriate and ineffective therapies. For bacterial pathogens which are naturally insensitive to a large number of classes of antimicrobials, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: Sclerotic bodies are seen in_________
questions.solution:
Sclerotic bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Histologically, the lesions in chromoblastomycosis show the presence of the fungus as round or irrergular, dark brown, thick-walled, muriform cells, yeast like bodies with septae called sclerotic bodies (medlar bodies). 

 

The lesions consist of warty, cutaneous nodules which resemble the florets of a cauliflower. The disease is usually confined to the subcutaneous tissue of the feet and lower legs.

The most common fungi responsible are of the genera: Fonsecaea, Exophiala dermatitidis, Phialophora and Cladophialophora.

Treatment:Surgical removal of lesions (cryosurgery or laser therapy) followed by antifungals (itraconazole).

questions.text: Werner syndrome is _______.
questions.solution:
Patients with Werner syndrome show premature aging. The defective gene product is DNA helicase, a protein involved in DNA replication, repair, and other functions that require DNA unwinding. The defect causes the rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage that may mimic injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging.

Option d:

Sirtuins are NAD-dependent protein deacetylases that function to adapt bodily functions to various environmental stresses. So, a defective sirtuin can lead to cellular aging. 

Note:

Werner syndrome should not be confused with Wermer syndrome, i.e. multiple endocrine neoplasias, type 1, a rare heritable disorder characterized by abnormalities involving the parathyroid, pancreas, and pituitary gland.

questions.text: Which of the following is common in patients with Kallmann syndrome?

choices.text: Syndactyly and hyperphagic obesity in males

questions.solution:
Anosmia is commonly seen in patients with Kallmann’s syndrome.

Kallmann syndrome:

  • It results from defective hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) synthesis and is associated with anosmia/hyposmia due to olfactory bulb agenesis/hypoplasia.
  • Classically, the syndrome may also be associated with colour blindness, optic atrophy, nerve deafness, cleft palate, renal abnormalities, cryptorchidism, and neurological abnormalities such as mirror movements.
  • GnRH deficiency prevents progression through puberty.
  • Males present with delayed puberty and pronounced hypogonadal features, including micropenis, which are results of low testosterone during infancy.
  • Females present with primary amenorrhea and failure of secondary sexual development.
  • Mutations in KAL1, FGF8, FGFR1, NELF, PROK2, PROK2R, and CHD7 have been described in patients with Kallmann’s syndrome.

Other options:

  • A white forelock is typical of Waardenburg syndrome.
  • Hyperphagic obesity is common in Prader-Willi syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is a minimum requirement for monitoring patients in shock?
questions.solution:
Pulse oximetry is one of the minimum requirements for monitoring patients in shock. Other minimum requirements include ECG, Blood Pressure and Urine output.

Monitoring for patients in shock

Minimum

  • ECG
  • Pulse oximetry
  • Blood Pressure
  • Urine Output

Additional modalities

  • Central venous pressure
  • Invasive blood pressure
  • Cardiac output
  • Base deficit and serum lactate

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about adipose tissue?

choices.text: No new adipose tissue is formed after the immediate postnatal period
Brown fat is found in the abdominal region in adults
Brown fat is a multilocular type of adipose tissue
Beige fat cells are a type of thermogenic fat cell

questions.solution:
Brown fat has been detected in adults, mainly in the supraclavicular region, in the neck and along the spine but not in the abdominal region.

It is characterized by the presence of large cells, containing several separate droplets of fat (multilocular adipose tissue) rather than a single globule.

No new adipose tissue forms after the immediate postnatal period.

Obesity is the enlargement of existing adipocytes due to excessive accumulation of lipid.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of anaplerotic reaction?
questions.solution:
Carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate is an example of anaplerotic reaction.

Anaplerotic reactions are chemical reactions that form intermediates of a metabolic pathway. It is an act of replenishing TCA cycle intermediates that have been extracted for biosynthesis.

Examples include:

  • Carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate
  • Transamination of aspartate to oxaloacetate by aspartate amino transferase
  • Hydration of glutamate to alpha-ketoglutarate-dehydrogenase
  • Beta oxidation of fatty acid to succinnyl–CoA
  • In purine synthesis and purine nucleotide cycle: Adenylosuccinate to fumarate catalysed by adenylosuccinate lyase.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child is brought to the pediatrician with the history of distension of abdomen and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and radiograph of the skull is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given features and x-ray showing a J-shaped sella and a thickened calvaria are suggestive of Hurler syndrome.

Hurler syndrome is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis type I (MPS I). It occurs due to a defect in α-L iduronidase, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler syndrome include:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs.
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies.

questions.text: A patient has dead space of 150 milliliters, FRC of 3 liters, Tidal Volume of 650 milliliters, ERV of 1.5 liters, TLC of 8 liters, and respiratory rate of 15 breaths/min. What is the alveolar ventilation ?
questions.solution:
Alveolar Ventilation rate (VA), measured in ml/min, is the rate of air flow that the gas exchange areas of the lung encounter during normal breathing. It is calculated by multiplying respiratory rate (RR) with the difference between tidal volume (VT) and dead space (VD).

Alveolar ventilation (VA) = RR (frequency) X (VT – VD).

Substituting the values: VA = 15 X (650 – 150) mL/min.

                                     VA = 7500 mL/min

                                     VA = 7.5 L/min

Hence, the alveolar ventilation in this case is 7.5 litres/min. 

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: Injury of the lower brachial plexus leads to Klumpke's paralysis. What is the characteristic clinical finding seen in this lesion?
questions.solution:
The characteristic clinical finding in Klumpke's paralysis is a complete claw hand.

Klumpke's paralysis is caused by injury of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus-mainly T1 and partially C8, due to traction injury of the lower trunk that may be seen in undue abduction of the arm (outstretched arm grabbing an object during a fall from height) or birth injury (traction of the extended arm during delivery) 

This leads to paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) that are responsible for flexion at metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP) and extension at proximal and distal interphalangeal joints(PIP and DIP). The unopposed action of extensor digitorum at MCP causes hyperextension. The unopposed action of flexor digitorum superficialis and profundus at PIP and DIP causes flexion. Thus giving rise to the characteristic claw hand.

Other changes include anesthesia and analgesia along the ulnar border of the forearm, vasomotor changes, absence of sweating, and trophic changes in long-standing cases. If the C8 is also damaged, the extent of anesthesia will be greater and will involve the medial side of the forearm, hand, and medial two fingers.

Horner's syndrome (option D) may occur in one-third of the cases due to injury of sympathetic fibers to the head and neck that leave the spinal cord through nerve T1.

The following image shows a complete claw hand in Klumpke's paralysis:

 

 

Other options:

Option A: Policeman tip deformity, also known as waiter's tip hand or porter's tip hand, is a finding of Erb's palsy due to injury of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus involving C5 and C6. The hand is adducted, medially rotated, and hangs by the side with the elbow extended and pronated. 

The following image shows policeman tip deformity in Erb's palsy:

 

Option B: Wrist drop is a feature of radial nerve injury in the axilla, radial groove, anterolateral side of the lower arm, or injury of the deep branch in the cubital fossa.

Option D: Horner's syndrome is caused due to the disruption of sympathetic supply to the face. It causes ptosis, miosis, anhydrosis, enophthalmos, and loss of ciliospinal reflex of the affected eye. It may occur in some cases of Klumpke's paralysis and is not a characteristic finding.

The following image shows the ocular manifestation of Horner syndrome:

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

Branches: 

 Parts 

Branches
Roots

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Long thoracic nerve of Bell (C5-C7)
Upper trunk

Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)

Nerve to Subclavius (C5, C6).
Lateral cord (LML)

Lateral pectoral nerve (C5-C7)

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)

Lateral root of median nerve (C5-C7)
Medial cord (UM4)

Medial pectoral (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (C8,T1)

Ulnar nerve (C8,T1)

Medial root of median nerve (C8,T1)
Posterior cord (STARS)

Upper Subscapular nerve (C5,C6)

Thoracodorsal nerve (C6-C8)

Axillary (C5,C6)

Radial (C5-T1)

Lower Subscapular (C5,C6)

 

Note : However Ulnar Nerve near its origin, often receives a communicating branch from the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord and carrying fibers from C7.

questions.text: Contrast induced nephropathy (CIN) is defined as:

choices.text: Rise in serum creatinine by 0.5 mg/dl in 48 hours
Rise in serum creatinine by 1 mg/dl in 48 hours
Rise in serum creatinine by 1.5 mg/dl in 48 hours
Rise in serum creatinine by 2 mg/dl in 48 hours

questions.solution:
CIN is defined as a rise in serum creatinine by 0.5 mg/dl within 48-72 hours of intravenous contrast administration.

The renal insufficiency should be acute, occurring within 2-3 days and should not be attributable to any other identifiable cause.

Hydration is a key measure to prevent CIN.

questions.text: A farmer from the sub Himalayan region presents with multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatics . The most likely causative agent is-
questions.solution:
Presence of multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a farmer (outdoor worker) from subhimalayan region suggests infection with Sporothrix schenckii.

Sporotrichosis: It is caused by thermally dimorphic fungi, Sporothrix schenckii.

Infection is introduced in skin by trauma (thron prick injury), hence sporotrichosis is called as Rose gardener’s disease. From the lesions in the skin and subcutaneous tissue, infection can spread via lymphatic channels to lymph nodes causing secondary ulcers on lymphnodes and lymphatics are hardened and cord like.

Systemic dissemination may occur to bone, joints and meninges.

Diagnosis:

  • Cigar shaped asteroid bodies in H & E stained tissue sections
  • Culture – flower like clusters of small conidia
  • Latex agglutination test
  • Skin test – delayed hypersensitivity to sporotrichin

Treatment:

  • Cutaneous infection – Potassium iodide-250mg thrice daily for 2-4 months                     
  • Lymphocutaneous infection - Itraconazole, fluconazole(400mg/day), terbinafine(250mg/day) and cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen
  • Disseminated infection - Amphotericin B

 

Related Pearl: Common names of various fungal infections

Disease

Common name

Histoplasmosis

Darling’s disease

Sporotrichosis

Rose-thorn or Rose gardener’s disease

Para-coccidioidomycosis

South American blastomycosis

Coccidioidomycosis

Valley fever or desert rheumatism

Blastomycosis

North American blastomycosis, Gilchrist's disease

questions.text: Mr. Kumar, a 60-year-old male had pain in the eye and visual disturbances 2 days after undergoing cataract surgery. The image of his eye is given below. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The image shows a picture of inflammation and hypopyon. This, along with the presentation of pain and visual disturbances acutely after cataract surgery suggest that the patient has developed endophthalmitis.

Endophthalmitis:

  • Cardinal features are pain, conjunctival or lid injection, and swelling and decrease in vision.
  • Postoperative endophthalmitis patient classically presents acutely within 7 days after surgery with inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and a hypopyon, due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber and posterior chamber.
  • The intravitreal injection of antibiotics has become the primary method of administration in the treatment of endophthalmitis. Other modalities of treatment include:
    • Topical antibiotic
    • Cycloplegia
    • Oral steroids
    • Pars plana vitrectomy

Toxic anterior segment syndrome is characterized by diffuse limbus-to-limbus corneal edema and anterior segment inflammation. The following points differentiate it from endophthalmitis

  • Vitreous inflammation is rare (vitreous inflammation present in endophthalmitis).
  • No pain/ little pain unless the IOP is very high. (Pain more often indicates endophthalmitis).
  • A fixed, dilated pupil–often with spotty or diffuse areas of iris atrophy. (Not seen in endophthalmitis)
  • Extremely high IOP early in the postoperative period is an unusual finding for endophthalmitis and points toward a diagnosis of TASS.
  • A therapeutic response to topical steroids is clearly present for several days in TASS, unlike in endophthalmitis, where the patient's condition worsens even after the application of topical steroids.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: An intern accidentally sent an incompletely labelled sample of the resected bowel wall from a patient with intestinal obstruction for histopathological examination. Given below is the microscopic image of the section of the sample. Which part of the gastrointestinal tract is being visualised here?
questions.solution:
The image is a section through the ileum as evident by the thin and slender villi and an aggregated lymphatic follicle (Peyer’s patch) in the submucosa.

These aggregations of lymphatic follicles are known as Mucosa Associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT), and also as gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT). Peyer's patches in submucosa are found in large size and numerously in the terminal ileum.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement about lippes loop?

choices.text: Type D has lower removal rate
Type D has higher anti fertility effects

questions.solution:
Type D lippes loop (largest type) has higher removal rates because of side effects such as pain and bleeding.

Lippes Loop: It belongs to 1st generation IUDs.

  • It comes in 4 sizes – A, B, C and D. A is the smallest and D is the largest.
  • It is an S shaped device, usually made of polyethylene.
  • The tail which is usually made of fine nylon, projects into the vagina after insertion.
  • The larger loops have higher rates of removal due to side effects but have greater anti-fertility effects.
  • Larger loops are usually used in multiparous women.
  • The Lippes Loop has minimal amount of barium sulphate in them to allow for X-ray observation.

questions.text: Hara-kiri is death by _____________
questions.solution:
Hara-kiri is death by stab in the abdomen.

Hara-kiri is an unusual type of suicide disembowelment connected with Japanese Samurai warriors. The victim with a short sword inflicts a single large abdominal stab wound into the left side, drawing the blade across to the right side and then turning it upwards producing an L-shaped cut. The sudden evisceration of the internal organs causes an immediate decrease in intraabdominal pressure and venous return resulting in collapse and death.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding partograph.

choices.text: Simplified type is amber coloured between alert line and action line
In composite type charting starts at 4cms dilation
Modified type has a latent phase

questions.solution:
Simplified WHO partograph is amber coloured between alert line and action line.

Modified WHO partograph does not have a latent phase and charting starts at 4cms dilation. On the contrary, Composite WHO partograph has a latent phase and charting starts at 3cms dilation.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A 25 yr old boy comes after a dog bite with hydrophobia, tearing and altered sensorium. You suspect rabies in this patient .Corneal scrapings has been taken.What test is done on it to get most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
On corneal scraping test done is RT-PCR. Detection of rabies virus RNA by RT-PCR(reverse transcriptase -polymerase chain reaction) is highly sensitive and specific.

This technique can detect virus in fresh saliva samples, CSF  , skin and brain tissues. RT-PCR with genetic sequencing can distinguish among rabies variants ,permitting identification of the probable source of an infection.

 Clinical stages of rabies:

PHASE TYPICAL DURATION SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS
Incubation period 20-90 Days None
Prodrome 2-10 days Fever,malaise , nausea ,vomiting,paresthesia
Acute neurologic disease    
Encephalitic/Furious rabies(80%) 2-7 days Anxiety,Agitation,Hyperactivity,hallucinations,hydrophobia,autonomic dysfunction
Paralytic /dumb rabies(20%) 2-10 days Flaccid paralysis in limbs progressing to quadriparesis with facial paralysis.
Coma ,death 0-14 days  (14 Days of encephalitic rabies and 30 days of paralytic rabies)

Other lab Diagnosis:

  • Once rabies suspected ,rabies -specific laboratory tests should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Diagnostic specimens: Serum,CSF,fresh saliva ,skin biopsy samples from neck and brain tissue .
  • Antibody detection- Rabies virus- specific antibodies in CSF is more significant than serum antibodies as serum antibodies appear late and can also be present after vaccination.
  • Rabies antigen detection-Direct fluorescent antibody testing with rabies virus antibodies conjugated to fluorescent dyes is highly sensitive and specific and can be performed quickly  and applied to skin biopsies and brain tissue.In skin biopsies ,rabies virus antigen may be detected  in cutaneous nerves at base of hair follicles.
  • Negri body detection - pathognomic for post mortem diagnosis of rabies.May not be detected in 20% of cases.Most common sites are neurons of cerebellum and hippocampus.

questions.text: Which hormone is not stored in its endocrine-producing gland?
questions.solution:
Aldosterone (produced in the adrenal cortex) and other steroid hormones are not stored to any appreciable extent in their endocrine producing glands.

In contrast, there are appreciable stores of thyroid hormones and peptide hormones in their endocrine-producing glands.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with a cough and shortness of breath. He has been working in a shipping factory for 30 years. On x-ray, a mass is seen in the right apical region of the lung. A biopsy sample is taken from the mass. Which of the following tumor markers is likely to be positive in this tumor?
questions.solution:
Calretinin is most likely to be positive in this tumour as the given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma.

Malignant mesothelioma is a rare malignant tumour of the pleura, associated with heavy asbestos exposure (shipping factory). The lifetime risk of developing mesothelioma in heavily exposed individuals is as high as 7% to 10%. 

It has strong male predilection (3:1). There is a long latent period of 25 to 45 years for the development of asbestos-related mesothelioma.

The image below shows a lung autopsy sample with mesothelioma.

Grossly, it appears as a diffuse lesion arising either from the visceral or parietal pleura. The affected lung becomes ensheathed by a thick layer of soft, gelatinous, grayish pink tumor tissue.

Microscopically, they are of three types: epithelioid (60%), sarcomatoid (20%), and mixed (20%).

Electron microscopy in mesothelioma will show numerous long, slender microvilli and abundant monofilaments but absent microvillous rootlets and lamellar bodies.

The image below shows the epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. Inset shows strong positivity for Calretinin immunostain.

Related Pearl: Differentiation of Mesothelioma from Adenocarcinoma

Immunohistochemical Results

Mesothelioma

Adenocarcinoma
Calretinin, WT-1, CK 5/6, D2-40 (Podoplanin)

Positive

Negative
TTF-1

Negative

Positive

Carcinoembryonic Antigen

Negative

Positive

Vimentin

Positive

Negative

Low molecular weight cytokeratins 

Positive

Negative

Electron microscopic features

Long, sinuous villi

Short, straight villi with fuzzy glycocalyx

questions.solution: The above image shows myopia since parallel rays of light are converging at a point in front of the retina. Out of the given options, conductive keratoplasty is not a surgical modality of treatment for myopia. Conductive ketratoplasty is a cornea based surgical procedure used in correction of Hypermetropia.

questions.text: A trumpet player presented with hoarseness of voice, cough, and a reducible neck swelling. The neck swelling increases in size on performing the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following regions would you expect to find a defect in?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of laryngocele. The defect is present in the saccule, represented by the area marked A in the above diagram.

The structures marked are: 

B. Ventricle

C. Vestibular ligament

D. Vocal ligament

The saccule is a pouch that ascends forwards from the anterior end of the ventricle, between the vestibular fold and thyroid cartilage.

It is conical in shape and contains around 60 and 70 mucous glands, sited in the submucosa.

It is separated from the thyroid cartilage by the thyroepiglotticus muscle which compresses the saccule. On compression, the secretions of the saccule are released into the vocal cords (which lack mucous glands) to lubricate and protect them from desiccation and infection. 

Clinical significance:

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised trans-glottic air pressure. It can be internal, external, or combined.

External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver.

Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and surgical excision through an external neck incision done for external laryngocele.

questions.text: The timing of primary repair surgery for cleft lip is?
questions.solution:
Primary repair for cleft lip should be done within 6months.

Surgery Timing

Cleft palate < 12 months
Repair of bone defect in cleft alveolus (gingivoperiosteoplasty) 12 months - 3 years

Orthognathic surgery > 17 years

questions.text: Drug of choice for rat bite fever is__________
questions.solution:
Drug of choice for rat bite fever is Penicillin G. It is considered to be treatment of choice for both forms of rat bite fever i.e Streptobacillus moniliformis and Spirillum minus. Penicillin resistance, though rare, but has been reported for S.moniliformis.

Alternative drug: Streptomycin, tetracyclin, doxycycline.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl, with a history of URTI, now presents with severe vomiting, lethargy, and altered mental status. You are suspecting Reye's syndrome. Which of the following liver biopsy findings will confirm your diagnosis?

choices.text: Portal tract edema and perisinusoidal fibrosis
Cirrhosis and periportal eosinophilic inclusion bodies

questions.solution:
The liver biopsy in Reye's syndrome will show marked microvesicular steatosis.

Reye's syndrome is an acute illness, encountered exclusively in children <15 years. Its onset usually follows upper respiratory tract infections. The actual cause is unknown, although viral agents and salicylates (aspirin) have been implicated.

Pathogenesis behind this condition is generalized mitochondrial dysfunction with structural and functional alterations of mitochondria in the liver, brain, and muscle. Liver is enlarged but jaundice is absent or minimum. It is characterized by clinical features such as:

  • Vomiting
  • Signs of progressive CNS damage
  • Signs of hepatic injury
  • Hypoglycemia

Extensive accumulation of fat droplets within hepatocytes (microvesicular steatosis) can be seen in histopathology. Extra-hepatic changes include fatty changes of renal tubular cells, cerebral edema, and neuronal degeneration of the brain.

The image given below shows microvesicular steatosis of liver.

Note: Aspirin is generally contraindicated in children, except in the treatment of Kawasaki disease and juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

questions.text: Which effect of ambulatory anesthesia most commonly persists after the patient is discharged?
questions.solution:
Drowsiness is the most common adverse effect that persists after discharge following an ambulatory or daycare anesthesia.

Adverse effects after ambulatory anesthesia in their decreasing order of incidence:

  1. Drowsiness
  2. Sore-throat
  3. Myalgia
  4. Headache, dizziness
  5. Nausea, vomiting
  6. Cardiovascular - hypotension, hypertension, arrhythmias, cardiac arrest (rare)
  7. Respiratory - hypoxemia, laryngospasm, bronchospasm, aspiration, pulmonary edema, pneumothorax (rare)

questions.text: A G2P1 patient at 25 weeks of gestation is brought to the emergency with right upper quadrant pain and one episode of seizure. CBC reveals a Hb of 7.6gm/dl and a platelet count of 70,000/microL. What is the definitive management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia and HELLP syndrome. The definitive management is the termination of pregnancy.

In cases of pre-eclampsia, indications for termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age, are as follows:

  • Eclampsia (give MgSO4 followed by induction of labor)
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Persistent symptoms of severe pre-eclampsia or severe hypertension
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy
  • Abruption of placenta
  • Fetal compromise

In mild pre-eclampsia, steroids are given and the patient is delivered at 37 weeks.

In severe pre-eclampsia:

  • If pregnancy is >34 weeks - MgSO4 is given for prophylaxis of eclampsia and the pregnancy is terminated.
  • If pregnancy is at 27-34 weeks - in the absence of contraindications, expectant management is followed and the baby is delivered at 34 weeks, as shown below in the flowchart.

questions.text: Which of the following is common in parvovirus infection in an adult?
questions.solution:
Parvovirus infection in adult commonly causes acute arthralgia and arthritis.

The characteristic feature of parvovirus arthritis is that it is peripheral, involves wrist, hand and knees. Arthritis resolves by three weeks and it is non destructive. Sometimes it is associated with a rash.

questions.text: All of the following are component-strains of vaccine given below, except _____________
questions.solution:
17D Strain is not a component of MMR vaccine. It is a strain of Yellow fever.

Disease Immunized Component Vaccine Virus Strain
Measles Attenuvax Enders' attenuated Edmonston strain

questions.text: Staging in a 60-year-old female patient with carcinoma endometrium showed involvement of >50% of the myometrium. There was no involvement of other structures and no lymph node involvement. Next line of management should be __________

choices.text: Post op pelvic radiotherapy + vaginal vault radiotherapy
Post op brachytherapy + post op external beam radiotherapy

questions.solution:
This is a case of stage 1B endometrial carcinoma since there is the involvement of >50% of the myometrium, with no involvement of other structures or lymph nodes. Stage 1B carcinoma endometrium is managed with post-op pelvic radiotherapy and vaginal vault radiotherapy.

Management of Ca Endometrium:

Surgical staging of Ca endometrium with total abdominal hysterectomy+bilateral salpingoophorectomy+lymphadenectomy is the cornerstone of treatment. Thus, further management is mainly postoperative. 

  • Stage IB: Postoperative pelvic radiotherapy over 5–6 weeks, along with vaginal vault radiotherapy.
  • Stage II: Brachytherapy followed by surgery and external radiotherapy either 1 week or 6 weeks later, based on histological findings. Alternately, Wertheim’s hysterectomy may be done.
  • Stage III: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin, cisplatin, and paclitaxel. Debulking surgery may be attempted.
  • Stage IV: Palliation with radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and progestogen

 

Related Pearl: Ca.Endometrium staging (Revised FIGO)

Related Pearl: Management of endometrial cancer

Surgery is done for staging of the cancer. The surgery done for this purpose is abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, and pelvic as well as para-aortic lymph node sampling.

Stage Treatment
IA noninvasive 
  • Surgery alone
IA
  • Surgery
  • Post-op radiotherapy
IB
  • Surgery
  • Post-op pelvic radiotherapy 4000-5000 cGy
  • Post-op vaginal vault radiotherapy
II
  • Surgery
  • Post-op brachytherapy
  • Post-op external beam radiotherapy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
III
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Chemotherapy with Doxorubicin+Cisplatin+Paclitaxel
  • Medroxyprogesterone adjuvant
IV
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Palliative radiotherapy/chemo/ progesterone therapy

*This pearl is in line with the FIGO 2010 guidelines. It will be updated according to the FIGO 2023 guidelines after an official treatment guideline is released.

questions.text: Caesarean delivery can be done in all of the following cardiovascular conditions except _________
questions.solution:
In case of Eisenmeinger’s syndrome, termination of pregnancy is advised. Caesrean delivery is indicated in other given conditions.

Simpson’s criteria for caesaerean delivery for cardiac disease in pregnancy:

  • Dilated aortic root >4 cm or aortic aneurysm.
  • Acute severe congestive heart failure.
  • Recent myocardial infarction.
  • Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis.
  • Warfarin administration within 2 weeks of delivery.
  • Need for emergency valve replacement immediately after delivery.

Other indications for caesarean delivery for cardiac disease in pregnancy:

  • Coarctation of aorta
  • Aortic dissection

Termination of pregnancy is indicated in WHO class 4 (Very high risk of maternal mortality or severe morbidity; pregnancy contraindicated). This includes:

  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension
  • Severe systemic ventricular dysfunction (NYHA III-IV or LVEF 30-40%)
  • Previous peripartum cardiomyopathy with any residual impairment of left ventricular function
  • Severe left heart obstruction
  • Marfan syndrome with aorta dilated >40 mm

Other heart diseases in which termination of pregnancy is advised:

  • Coarctation of aorta
  • Eisenmenger syndrome

questions.text: A man presented to the OPD for a routine examination and chalky white deposits were found on his tympanic membrane. His hearing tests are normal. Which of the following statements is incorrect about his condition?

choices.text: Debridement of the chalky deposits must be performed
There is a prior history of inflammation of the middle ear
Grommets increase the incidence of this condition

questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this case is tympanosclerosis. Tympanosclerotic chalky depositis in the middle ear without any clinical symptoms should not be removed.

Tympanosclerosis is a scarring process with a remarkable variability in its localization within the middle ear. It can lead to conductive hearing. It is usually caused by recurrent chronic inflammation of the middle ear. When the tympanic membrane is involved without any symptoms it is called myringosclerosis.
A significant increase in tympanosclerosis in seen in ears in which grommets were placed compared with the contralateral ears, in which only myringotomy was performed.

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for post-polio syndrome?

choices.text: Decreasing length of time from acute polio infection

questions.solution:
Permanent impairment after recovery is a risk factor post polio syndrome.

Post polio syndrome: After an interval of 30-40 years, around 30-40% of persons who survived paralytic poliomyelitis in childhood, experience muscle pain and exacerbation of existing weakness or development of new weakness or paralysis. It is known as postpolio syndrome. It has been reported only in persons who were infected in the era of wild-type poliovirus circulation.

Risk factors for postpolio syndrome include:

  • Permanent impairment after recovery from acute polio infection
  • Increasing length of time from acute polio infection
  • Female sex

questions.text: A newborn baby has respiratory distress in the delivery room. Attempts to pass a nasogastric tube through both the nares are unsuccessful. Genital and ear abnormalities are also noted on the preliminary examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Inability to pass the nasogastric tube through both the nares along with the presence of respiratory distress, suggests choanal atresia. The presence of ear and genital anomalies along with choanal atresia suggests the diagnosis of CHARGE syndrome.

It consists of

  • Coloboma of the eye
  • Heart anomaly
  • Choanal Atresia
  • Retardation
  • Genital anomalies
  • Ear anomalies

VATER syndrome: Vertebral defects, imperforate anus, tracheoesophageal fistula, as well as radial and renal dysplasia.

Potter's sequence: Renal agenesis, oligohydramnios, and pulmonary hypoplasia

Pierre–Robin syndrome: Micrognathia, retrognathia, and glossoptosis.

questions.text: Which of the following given statements regarding the aorta is true?

choices.text: The adjacent left superior intercostal vein is seen on X-ray as the aortic nipple
A larger aortic nipple is called an aortic knob
The aortic arch is best visualised in left posterior oblique views
Ascending aorta originates at the base of the left ventricle and ascends obliquely curving to the left

questions.solution:
An aortic nipple is seen in about 10% of PA chest x-rays on the lateral surface of the aortic knob. It represents the left superior intercostal vein.

The aortic arch is best visualized in left anterior oblique view. Ascending aorta originates at the base of the left ventricle at the level of inferior border of the third left costal cartilage, and ascends obliquely, curving anteriorly and to the right. It is the arch of aorta that curves left.

questions.text: The resin exuding from the leaves and stems of Indian hemp is called:
questions.solution:
The resin exuding from the leaves and stems of Indian hemp is called charas.

Charas is a dark green or brown color resin. It is usually mixed and smoked with tobacco in a pipe, smoke is inhaled deeply into the lungs and retained as long as possible for potent effects. It contains 25-40% of the active principle (tetrahydrocannabinol).

Indian hemp or Cannabis sativa is a CNS stimulant. The principal constituent is cannabinol which has no action but on exposure to heat, it gets converted to a very active isomeric tetrahydrocannabinol. The active component is present in all parts of the plant. 

Different preparations of cannabis include: 

Bhang

  • Prepared from dried leaves and fruit shoot
  • Mildest
  • Contains 15% of active principle
  • Used as we use tea to prepare a decoction

Majoon

  • Sweet prepared with bhang
  • Increases appetite and sexual desire

Ganja

  • Prepared from flower tops of the female plant
  • Contains 15-25% of active principle
  • Mixed and smoked with tobacco in a pipe or hukka

questions.text: A child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Very long-chain fatty acids are accumulated in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome.

Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, also known as Zellweger's syndrome, is a rare inherited disorder characterised by the absence of peroxisomes in all tissues. It is caused by mutations in the genes encoding peroxins, which take part in peroxisome biosynthesis. There is accumulation of C26-C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissues along with generalised loss of peroxisomal functions. Patients present with severe neurological symptoms and most die within a year. Other biochemical findings include abnormalities in the bile acid synthesis and a decreased plasmalogens.

questions.text: Premature menopause is menopause occurring before ___________
questions.solution:
Premature menopause is menopause occurring before 40 years.

The average age of menopause is 47 years and the range is between 45 to 50 years.

questions.text: A young man experiences a sudden onset of severe headache, breathlessness, and blurred vision while trekking on a mountain. Which of the following physiological factors has no role in this condition?

choices.text: Altered permeability of blood brain barrier
Release of calcium from endoplasmic reticulum
Increase in vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of sudden onset of severe headache, breathlessness, and blurred vision while trekking on a mountain suggests high-altitude cerebral edema. Calcium release from the endoplasmic reticulum has no role in high-altitude cerebral edema.

At high altitudes, the partial pressure of oxygen in the atmosphere is low. When people ascend to high altitudes hypoxia causes systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue and lungs. This results in cerebral edema and pulmonary edema respectively.

Pathophysiology: Vasogenic edema occurs due to the leaking of proteins and fluid through the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Causes of increased BBB permeability include:

  • Mechanical factors- loss of autoregulation and increased capillary pressure due to increased sympathetic activity (option D).
  • Increased chemical mediators of permeability- vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), nitric oxide, and cytokines (options A and C).

Patients with cerebral edema usually present with headache, and papilledema leading to a blurring of vision, breathlessness (due to hypoxia), nausea, and vomiting

Treatment involves the administration of oxygen and descent to a lower altitude. Nifedipine can be given as adjunct therapy.

Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high-altitude areas.

Related Pearl: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: Fingerprinting (FINDER ) involves recording prints of 8 fingers. Which finger pair is excluded ?
questions.solution:
The finger pair excluded by FINDER are little finger.

Fingerprint reader is a computerized automatic fingerprint reading system which can record each fingerprint data in half second. Prints of eight fingers are recorded excluding little fingers. The light reflected from a fingerprint can be measured and converted  to digital data which is classified codified and stored in the computer.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about transfusion-related acute lung injury?

choices.text: Mediated by anti-HLA antibodies in recipient plasma
Usually develops within 6 hours after transfusion
Plasma transfusion from nulliparous females decreased incidence

questions.solution:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is mediated by anti-HLA antibodies in the donor plasma, not the recipient plasma. 

TRALI is characterized by the development of hypoxia due to noncardiogenic pulmonary edema (option C) following a transfusion. It usually develops within 6 hours (option B) following transfusion, but delayed cases can present up to 72 hours. TRALI occurs due to transfusion of donor plasma that has high-titers of anti-HLA class II antibodies. Anti-HLA class I and anti-human neutrophil antigen antibodies are also involved. 

Transfusion of plasma and platelet concentrates from male donors and nulliparous females has been shown to reduce the incidence of TRALI significantly (option D). Recipient risk factors that increase the incidence of TRALI include smoking, alcohol consumption, and shock. Once features of TRALI develop in a patient, the treatment is supportive.

questions.text: All of the following are protease inhibitors, except ?
questions.solution: Tenofovir is nucleotide phosphonate reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) and not a protease inhibitor.

questions.text: True about organophosphate-induced delayed polyneuropathy are all except:

choices.text: Involves both sensory and motor nerve

questions.solution:
There is no specific therapy for Organophosphate Induced Delayed Polyneuropathy (OPIDN). Regular physiotherapy may limit deformity caused by muscle wasting.

OPIDN:

  • It is a rare, delayed neurotoxic effect, which occurs 1-5 weeks after severe toxicity from some cholinesterase inhibitors.
  • No specific treatment has been identified. The early administration of pralidoxime and atropine doesn’t seem to prevent the condition.
  • Patients with mild cases recover over several months; those with more serious polyneuropathy have persistent effects.
  • Recovery affects only sensory nerves, while motor neurons may permanently lose function.

Option A has been revised to be more factually accurate. However, the best possible answer choice remains Option C as steroids are not used in the treatment since there is no specific treatment for OPIDN.

questions.text: Sunita, a 28 year old female was brought to ER following abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, preceded by amenorrhea for 8 weeks. She has a past history ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg and pulse rate of 94 beats/minute, with urine pregnancy test positive. The next step of management would be ______
questions.solution:
In this case scenario, the next step of management would be a transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS)  as she has a high likelihood of ectopic pregnancy.

In any woman of the reproductive age group, with amenorrhoea, positive urine pregnancy test and hemodynamically stable vaginal bleeding, TVUS is the next step of management to rule out abortion or ectopic pregnancy. If the TVUS is non-diagnostic, then serum quantitative beta hCG is evaluated.

In a similar case scenario with unstable vitals, transabdominal scan/FAST may be performed, to assess quickly for intraperitoneal hemorrhage. If positive, it is an ectopic pregnancy until proven otherwise and Laprotomy is performed.

This MCQ has been revised as a whole to reflect the accurate steps of management for a woman with suspected ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: Pelkan spur is a finding seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Pelkan spur is a radiological finding seen in Scurvy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids cannot be phosphorylated using protein kinase in prokaryotic organisms?
questions.solution:
Asparagine cannot be phosphorylated using protein kinase in prokaryotic organisms.

Protein kinase phosphorylate proteins by catalysing transfer of the terminal phosphoryl group of ATP to the hydroxyl groups of seryl, threonyl or tyrosyl residues forming o-phosphoseryl, o-phosphothreonyl, o-phosphotyrosyl residues, respectively.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Mid tracheostomy is done at which of the following levels of tracheal cartilage?
questions.solution:
Mid tracheostomy is performed at the level of 2-3 tracheal cartilage rings.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Sipple syndrome?
questions.solution:
Multiple endocrine neoplasia(MEN) 2A which is also known as sipple syndrome, is characterized by pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma and parathyroid hyperplasia (not hyperthyroidism).

Cause: Germline gain of function mutation in the RET proto-oncogene on chromosome 10q 11.2.

Components:

  • Medullary thyroid of carcinoma occur in almost 100%  of the patients,usually multifocal and virtually always associated with foci of C-cell hyperplasia in the adjacent thyroid.
  • 40 to 50% have pheochromocytomas, often bilateral and may rise in extra adrenal sites.
  • In 10 to 20% patients parathyroid hyperplasia occurs and there is evidence of hypercalcemia and renal stones.

Familial medullary thyroid cancer is a variant of MEN 2A,in which there is a strong predisposition to medullary thyroid cancer but not other clinical manifestations.

In MEN 2B more aggressive medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytomas occur but no primary hyperthyroidism. In addition neuromas or ganglioneuromas involving skin, oral, eyes, respiratory tract and gastrointestinal tract and marfanoid habitus are seen.

questions.text: Test shown in the image is useful for the detection of ________________
questions.solution:
The test shown in the photograph is rapid plasma reagin test used to detect Treponema pallidum.

RPR test is one of the nonspecific tests  commonly used to screen the population for syphilis. The RPR test measures IgM and IgG antibodies to lipoidal material released from damaged host cells as well as to lipoprotein-like material, and possibly cardiolipin released from the treponemes.

Antigen used in RPR Test:

RPR antigen contains cardiolipin, lecithin, cholesterol, 10% choline chloride, EDTA, charcoal etc in buffer. The test uses the VDRL antigen containing fine carbon particle ,which makes result more clear cut and evident to naked eye.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis.

It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. 

Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods. 

  • Fontana's method is used on smear
  • Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections

The clinical manifestations of syphilis include:

Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.

Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.

Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the classic iritis or uveitis.

Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman may infect the fetus in utero. 

Neurosyphilis:  The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.

Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.

Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly,  lymphadenopathy , anemia
, jaundice,  thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)

Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: Which is the most common tumour arising in Meckel’s diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Neoplasms can also occur in a Meckel’s diverticulum, with neuroendocrine tumors (carcinoid tumors) as the most common malignant neoplasm.

Other histologic types include adenocarcinoma (11%), which generally originates from the gastric mucosa, and gastrointestinal stromal tumours (10%) and lymphoma (1%).

Meckel's diverticulum has equal incidence in men and women and is the most common congenital anomaly of the small intestine. It is situated on the antimesenteric border of the ileum, usually 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve, and occurs due to incomplete closure of the vitelline duct. It is a true diverticulum consisting of all layers. 

It can present as:

  • Incidental findings during surgery
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in the form of hemorrhage in children
  • Intestinal obstruction in the form of volvulus, intussusception (urge to defecate, vomiting, red current stools) 
  • Diverticulitis (right lower quadrant pain)

In children, 99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in Meckel's diverticulum and is the most accurate diagnostic modality. However, in adults, less ectopic gastric tissue is seen, so the test is not very accurate. The sensitivity and specificity can be improved by the use of cimetidine.

In case of false-negative results, barium studies, mesenteric arteriography, or double-balloon endoscopy can be used for diagnosis.

Treatment is diverticulectomy or segmental resection of ileum containing diverticulum. In children, an incidentally found asymptomatic diverticulum has to be resected. 

The image below shows Meckel's diverticulum.

Related Pearl: Rule of two’s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Located approx 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • Approx 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.
  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, and the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images. 

Other options: 

Option A: In T1 weighted images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Option C: FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

Option D: STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.

Related Pearl: T1 vs T2 MRI

questions.text: A child is diagnosed to have an aneurysmal malformation of a vessel located in the marked structure. Identify the structure and the vessel present in it.
questions.solution:
The area marked "A" is the quadrigeminal cistern, and it contains the great cerebral vein of Galen.

Aneurysmal malformation of the great cerebral vein of Galen is a congenital anomaly occurring due to the persistence of the embryonic prosencephalic vein of Markowski. 

The image below is a CT cerebral angiogram of a vein of Galen malformation and an abnormal falcine sinus.

Related Pearl: Subarachnoid Cisterns

Subarachnoid cistern Interpeduncular / basal cistern Cisterna Magns ( Cerebellomedullary cistern )- largest cistern Quadrigeminal cistern/ Superior cistern/ vein of Galen cistern/ Peripineal cistern Cerebellopontine cistern Pontine cistern Sylvian/Lateral sulcus cistern
Location Base of brain in the interpeduncular fossa Angle between the inferior surface of cerebellum and medulla. Continuous with the IV ventricle through foramen of Magendie Between the splenium of corpus callosum and superior cerebellar surface behind the midbrain Lateral angle between the cerebellum and pons Ventral surface of the pons Over the lateral sulcus
