Great cerebral vein of Galen V, VII and VIII cranial nerves, anterior inferior cerebellar arteries, superior petrosal veins Basilar artery Middle cerebral artery and veins

questions.text: Oniomania  is a disorder of compulsive______________
questions.solution: Oniomania is a disorder of compulsive buying.

questions.text: In what condition would you see the gallbladder as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a strawberry gallbladder. Strawberry gallbladder is seen in cholesterolosis and is associated with cholesterol stones.

Cholesterolosis is characterized by mucosal villous hyperplasia. The interior of the gallbladder resembles a strawberry. The yellow specks are aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters in the lamina propria. This corresponds to the seeds of a strawberry.

Option A: Cholesterol polyposis - Cholecystography or ultrasonography shows negative shadows in a functioning gallbladder, indicating the presence of a well-defined polyp.

Options B and C: Cholecystitis glandularis proliferans/adenomyomatosis - All layers of the gallbladder wall may be thickened, but sometimes, an incomplete septum forms that separate the hyperplastic from the normal layer. Intraparietal "mixed" calculi may be present.

questions.text: A factory worker comes to you with itchy, annular scaly plaques in the groin. On prescribing corticosteroids ointment, there is significant relief in pruritus but the lesion continues to extend peripherally. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Itchy annular plaques in the groin with peripheral extension is highly suggestive of Tinea cruris which is a dermatophytosis of the groin region caused by Trichophyton rubrum (other agents include Epidermophyton floccosum).

It is the second most common dermatophytosis worldwide involving groin, pubic and perineal skin and genitalia.

Usually seen on the inner aspect of thighs as arcuate sharply demarcated plaques with peripheral scaling, papulo-vesiculation, and pustulation.

Chronic lesions may show hyperpigmentation, nodulation, and lichenification in the center. Lesion expand centrifugally and the center clears.

 

Steroids cause relief from itching but do not cause cure of the infection.

Treatment:- Terbinafine or Itraconazole or Fluconazole or Griseofulvin for 2-4 weeks.

questions.text: A young female presented with vaginal itching and green frothy genital discharge. Strawberry cervix is seen on examination. What will be the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Vaginal itching and green frothy discharge in a young female with strawberry vagina points towards trichomoniasis. Metronidazole is the drug of choice for trichomoniasis.

It is is the most common parasitic infection in humans in the industrialized world.

It is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, an anaerobic, flagellated protozoa, exists only as a trophozoite (no cyst stage).

Diagnosis is made by detection of motile flagella during microscopic examination of wet mounts. Direct immunofluorescent antibody staining is more sensitive (70-90%) than wet mount.

Culture is done on Feinberg-Whittington media.

Treatment: DOC- Metronidazole 2 gm single oral dose. All sexual partners must be treated to prevent reinfection, especially from asymptomatic males. Tinidazole can also be used for the treatment of trichomoniasis.

The image below shows strawberry vagina seen in trichomoniasis:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented with the following skin finding. On inquiry, he also tells you that his father has similar complaints. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a periungual fibroma or Koenen tumor, which is characteristic of tuberous sclerosis (TS). They appear at or after puberty as smooth, firm, flesh-colored excrescences emerging from the nail folds. 

Other cutaneous features of tuberous sclerosis:

  • Angiofibromas - Firm, discrete, red-brown, telangiectatic papules, 1 to 10 mm in diameter that become more extensive at puberty and then remain unchanged. They extend from the nasolabial furrows to the cheeks and chin and are occasionally found in the ears.
  • Shagreen patch - An irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, soft, skin-colored plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region.
  • Ash-leaf macule - White ovoid or ash‐leaf‐shaped macules, 1–3 cm in length, most easily detectable by examination under Wood’s light, are frequently present on the trunk or limbs. They are a valuable physical sign as they may be found at birth or in early infancy, some years before other signs of the disease develop.
  • Other cutaneous manifestations- include firm fibromatous plaques, especially on the forehead and scalp, soft pedunculated fibromas around the neck and axillae, and poliosis.

questions.text: All of the following are provisions of prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT) services for HIV except ______________

choices.text: An opt out option from HIV counselling/testing to pregnant mothers
Triple regimen ART therapy to HIV+ pregnant women based on their CD4 count
ARV prophylaxis to infants of HIV+ mothers up to 6 weeks
Use of HIV DNA PCR at 6 weeks after birth

questions.solution:
Lifelong Triple regimen ART therapy (TDF+3TC+FFV) is given to HIV+ pregnant and breastfeeding women regardless of their CD4 count and clinical stage of HIV.

*Note: Pearl attached below has been updated according to the NACO ART guidelines 2021. Efavirenz has been replaced by Dolutegravir as per the new guidelines.

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: The drug most useful in a patient with hepatic encephalopathy is:
questions.solution:
Lactulose is used to treat hepatic encephalopathy.

  • Lactulose is a laxative that acts by getting converted to short chain fatty acid in the colon.
  • These fatty acids result in decrease in pH of intestinal juice.
  • At this low pH, ammonia becomes ionized and thus cannot be absorbed.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being found in his garden confused and somnolent. He was outside trimming the hedges with an electric cutter on a hot summer day for about 2-3 hours prior to being found by his wife. He has a history of mild-moderate systolic heart failure, and his medications include atorvastatin, metoprolol and losartan. He works as a TSA officer in the airport. On examination, he is difficult to arouse and confused, with a heart rate of 120 bpm, BP of 100/50 mmHg saturation of 97% on room air, and a temperature of 105-degree Fahrenheit. His skin is dry and warm with the rest of the physical examination unremarkable. His laboratory studies are notable for a sodium of 146 mEq/L, potassium of 3.8mEq/L, creatinine kinase of 250 U/L, glucose of 120 mg/L, BUN of 35 mg/dL, and creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Classic heatstroke is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario.

Heatstroke:

  • The classical manifestations of heat stroke reflect a total loss of thermoregulatory function. Typical vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, various tachycardias, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure.
  • Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, the historical and physical triad of exposure to heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and core temperature of more than 104.9-degree Fahrenheit (> 40.5 degrees Celsius) helps establish the preliminary diagnosis.
  • Heat exhaustion is distinguished from heatstroke by the loss of thermoregulatory control, typically manifested by a core body temperature of > 40.5-degree C, in case of heat stroke. The physiologic precipitants of heat exhaustion are water and sodium depletion.
  • There are two forms of heat stroke with different manifestations:
CLASSIC HEAT STROKE EXERTIONAL HEAT STROKE
Older patients Younger patient
Predisposing health factors/medications Healthy condition
Epidemiology (heat waves) Sporadic cases
Sedentary Exercising
Anhidrosis (possible) Diaphoresis (common)
CNS dysfunction Myocardial/hepatic injury
Oliguria Acute renal failure
Coagulopathy (mild) Disseminated intravascular coagulation
Mild lactic acidosis Marked lactic acidosis
Mild creatinine kinase elevation Rhabdomyolysis
Normoglycemia/Calcaemia Hypoglycemia/Calcemia
Normokalemia Hyperkalemia

Other options:

  • The absence of focal neurological findings, elevated creatinine kinase (normal range=25-200 U/L), and precipitating medications make the other mentioned diagnoses less likely.

questions.text: The following deformity shown in the image below is characteristically seen in ___________
questions.solution:
The image given above shows windswept deformity (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg) which is characteristically seen in rickets. However, it may also be seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

Other deformities of extremities seen in Rickets:

  • Enlargement of wrists and ankles
  • Valgus or Varus deformities of limbs
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia and femur
  • Coxa vara

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about joints?

choices.text: The three types of fibrous joints are sutures, gomphoses and symphysis
A Peg-and-socket junction between a tooth and its socket is a type of fibrous joint
A schindylesis is a specialized suture joint
All symphyses occur in the midline

questions.solution:
The three types of fibrous joints are sutures, gomphoses and syndesmoses.

A gomphosis is a peg-and-socket junction between a tooth and its socket.

A schindylesis is a specialized suture in which a ridged bone fits into a groove on a neighbouring element, e.g. where the cleft between the alae of the vomer receives the rostrum of the sphenoid.

All symphyses occur in the midline (mandibular, manubriosternal, pubic and intervertebral) and all except the mandibular symphysis occur in the postcranial skeleton and resist synostosis.

questions.text: A patient developed the following lesions after 10 days of initiation of chemotherapy. The patient also complains of similar lesions over soles and they are sensitive to touch. Which is the most likely agent to cause this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts classical findings of hand-foot syndrome and capecitabine is commonly associated with this prominent side effect.

Hand foot syndrome or palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia consists of erythema, desquamation, pain and sensitivity to touch of the palms and soles. 

Drugs commonly implicated are:

  • Capecitabine
  • 5-Fluorouracil
  • Cytarabine
  • Pemetrexed
  • Doxorubicin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about vocal fold varices?

choices.text: Serial laryngovideostroboscopy is used to study the varices
Improvement of vocal hygiene helps in management of the lesion
Varices increase in the post menstrual phase

questions.solution:
Varices may enlarge premenstrually and menstrually and can increase a singer’s dysphonia.

A true vocal fold varix is a dilated, tortuous, or elongated blood vessel that stems from the microcirculation of the vocal fold; it occurs mainly in female professional vocalists. If a vascular lesion is found, its functional significance should be determined.  This determination is best made with serial laryngovideostroboscopy.

Nonsurgical management of vascular lesions involves improvement in vocal hygiene, particularly with increased water intake and the avoidance of caffeine.

Indications for surgery include recurrent hemorrhage, an enlarging varix, and continued dysphonia despite maximum medical and behavioral management.

questions.text: Which of the following describes lateral aberrant thyroid?

choices.text: Defective development of the fourth pharyngeal pouch
Metastatic thyroid cancer in lymph nodes
Cystic swelling of the thyroglossal duct

questions.solution:
Lateral aberrant thyroid almost always represents metastatic thyroid cancer in lymph nodes.

Thyroid tissue situated lateral to the carotid sheath and jugular vein found along the course of the thyroglossal duct was previously termed lateral aberrant thyroid. It is associated with papillary thyroid cancer in the ipsilateral thyroid lobe.

The image given below shows the lateral aberrant thyroid.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: Risk of malignancy index for ovarian cancer takes into account all except _________
questions.solution:
The risk of malignancy index for ovarian cancer takes into account the presence of menopause, CA 125 levels and ultrasound findings. Age of the patient is not considered.

RMI is a tool to differentiate between benign and malignant ovarian mass. When the value is 200 or less than that it is benign if the value is above 200 it is considered malignant. M=1 for premenopausal women, M=3 for postmenopausal women.

Risk of Malignancy Index: 

RMI = U x M x CA125

  • U= Ultrasound score. The ultrasound result is scored 1 point for each of the following characteristics: multilocular cysts, solid areas, metastases, ascites and bilateral lesions. U = 0 (for an ultrasound score of 0), U = 1 (for an ultrasound score of 1), U = 3 (for an ultrasound score of 2–5).

  • M= Menopausal status. The menopausal status is scored as 1 = pre-menopausal and 3 = post-menopausal

  • CA125= Serum CA125 level (IU/ml)

questions.text: All are true regarding Tumour Lysis Syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Hypocalcaemia (and not hypercalcemia) is seen in Tumour Lysis Syndrome (TLS).

Tumour Lysis Syndrome is caused by destruction of large number of rapidly multiplying neoplastic cells: Burkitt’s lymphoma, ALL, CLL on chemotherapy.

Acute hyperuricemic nephropathy occurs when urinary uric acid/urine creatinine >1.

  • Characteristic biochemical changes in TLS:
    • Hyperuricemia
    • Hyperkalaemia
    • Hypocalcaemia
    • Hyperphosphatemia
    • Acidosis
    • Acute renal failure
  • Drugs commonly associated are:
    • Fludarabine
    • Letrozole
    • Tamoxifen
    • Rituximab
    • Also, glucocorticoids
  • High risk for TLS:
    • Tumour burden
    • Hyperuricemia
    • High LDH
  • Treatment:
    • Allopurinol
    • Rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase (contraindicated in G6PD deficiency, can cause bronchospasm, hypotension, and hypoxia).
    • Aggressive treatment with ½ N.S
    • Urinary alkalization to pH >7 with sodium bicarbonate.
    • Hemodialysis/hemofiltration if:
      • S. potassium > 6
      • S. uric acid > 10
      • S. phosphate > 10
      • S. creatinine >10 with severe hypocalcaemia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

  • Parathyroid-Related
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
      • Adenoma(s)
      • Multiple endocrine neoplasia
      • Carcinoma
    • Lithium therapy
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Malignancy-Related
    • Solid tumour with metastases (breast)
    • Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)
    • Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Vitamin D–Related
    • Vitamin D intoxication
    • ↑ 1,25(OH)2D :
      • Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases
      • Impaired 1,25(OH)2D metabolism due to 24-hydroxylase deficiency
    • Associated with high bone turnover
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Immobilization
      • Thiazides
      • Vitamin A intoxication
      • Fat necrosis
    • Associated with renal failure
      • Severe secondary hyperparathyroidism
      • Aluminium intoxication
      • Milk-alkali syndrome

questions.text: Kirk’s arterial arcade, which supplies the head of the pancreas, is formed by all the following arteries except?

choices.text: Left branch of the Dorsal pancreatic artery
Right branch of the dorsal pancreatic artery

questions.solution:
The Left branch of the dorsal pancreatic artery is not a part of Kirk’s arcade.

Kirk’s arcade in the pancreas :

  • It is formed by the anastomosis of:
    • a right branch of the dorsal pancreatic artery (anterior surface of the pancreas)
    • a branch of either the gastroduodenal or the anterior pancreaticoduodenal arcade.
  • It supplies blood to the ventral surface of the head and neck of the gland.

questions.text: The drug not used for immediate treatment of acute hyperkalemia is ____?
questions.solution:
Potassium exchange resins are not used for the immediate treatment of hyperkalemia.

Treatment of hyperkalemia: 

Immediate measures : 

1. Immediate antagonism of the cardiac effects of hyperkalemia with intravenous calcium. It reverses the depolarisation blockade due to hyperkalemia and prevents arrhythmias.  

2. Rapid reduction in plasma K+ concentration by redistribution into cells

  • Insulin followed by a bolus of Dextrose
  • A beta-2 agonist (like inhaled albuterol)

Delayed measures:  (removal of potassium from blood): Cation exchange resins, diuretics, and dialysis.   

 NOTE: Although sodium bicarbonate can theoretically be used to shift the potassium intracellular, it is not used for the management of acute hyperkalemia. Sodium bicarbonate may be used in hyperkalemia with concomitant acidosis.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with acute onset fever and dysuria. Urinalysis reveals plenty of leukocytes with glycosuria. A CT scan of the abdomen is performed, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, along with the CT scan showing an enlarged kidney with areas of necrosis and mottled areas of gas collection, is suggestive of left-sided emphysematous pyelonephritis.

Emphysematous pyelonephritis is a severe, acute, necrotizing infection of the kidney caused by gas-producing organisms. It predominantly affects diabetic patients who are particularly susceptible due to their hyperglycemic state, which promotes bacterial growth and fermentation. The most common causative organism is Escherichia coli, which ferments sugar to produce carbon dioxide, leading to gas accumulation within renal parenchyma or perinephric tissues. Less commonly, organisms like Klebsiella and Proteus species can also cause this condition.  

Almost all patients present with fever, vomiting and flank pain. Patients frequently present with sepsis and ketoacidosis. If not treated early, it may lead to fulminant sepsis and is associated with high mortality. 

The diagnosis is primarily established radiographically, with a CT scan being the investigation of choice in identifying the extent of the emphysematous process and guiding management. The following diagnostic features are seen:

  • Enlarged, destructed renal parenchyma
  • Small bubbly or linear streaks of gas
  • Fluid collections, with gas-fluid levels
  • Focal necrotic areas with or without abscess

questions.text: A person of eonism  derives pleasure from __________.

choices.text: Kissing  and licking of anus by a sexual partner

questions.solution:
A person of eonism (transvestism) derives pleasure from wearing clothes of the opposite sex. It is usually found in males. His dress, manner, occupational interests, and associations are all designed to increase his feeling of being a woman.

Other options:

Sexual pleasure from

  • Kissing and licking of anus by a sexual partner - Anilingus
  • Sexual interest in nonliving objects that are used to generate sexual excitement.  -Fetichism
  • Seeing a female undressing - Voyeurism or scoptophilia

questions.text: What is the fluid requirement of a 50 kg man with first degree burns to his left arm and leg, circumferential second degree burns to his right upper limb and third degree burns to his posterior torso and right lower limb. What is the rate of initial fluid resuscitation?

choices.text: 2.25L over 8 hours, followed by 2.25L over 16 hours
4.5 L over 8 hours, followed by 4.5 L over 16 hours
6 L over 8 hours, followed by 6 L over 16 hours
9 L over 8 hours, followed by 9 L over 16 hours

questions.solution:
Total volume of fluid needed is 4.5 litres of which 2.25L is given in first 8 hours and 2.25L is given in next 16 hours as indicated by 

Step 1: Calculating % of burns using rule of nines

  • This includes only 2nd and 3rd degree burns.
  • Right upper limb + right lower limb and posterior torso = 9 + 18 + 18 = 45%

STEP 2 : Calculating fluid using resucitation formula for thermal burns - 2ml x 50(kg) x 45(TBSA%) = 4.5 litres.

 

Note:

According to new ATLS 10th ed 2018 guidelines, the resuscitation formula for thermal burns is 2ml/kg/TBSA%. The fluid requirement during the initial 24 hours of treatment is 2 mL/kg of body weight for each percent of TBSA burned, given IV. Superficial (epidermal) burns are excluded from this calculation. One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first eight hours, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours. The rate of infusion for IV resuscitation fluid should be as constant as possible; sharp decreases in infusion rates can lead to vascular collapse and an increase in edema

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A surgeon performing a modified radical mastectomy decides to remove the pectoralis minor and level III lymph nodes but preserve the pectoralis major. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The given procedure where pectoralis minor and level III lymph nodes are removed but pectoralis major was preserved is Patey's modified radical mastectomy. 

Patey's modified radical mastectomy is a total mastectomy. It includes removal of the breast tissue and axillary lymph nodes up to level III along with the removal of pectoralis minor muscle, but pectoralis major is preserved.

Other options:

Option A: Scanlon’s modified radical mastectomy is a modification of Patey's procedure in which pectoralis minor is incised and not removed following which the level III nodes are approached. 

Option C: Halsted radical mastectomy involves excision of the breast tissue, skin, and nipple-areolar complex, dissection of level I, II, and III axillary lymph nodes, and pectoralis major and minor muscles. 

Option D: In, Auchincloss modified radical mastectomy, pectoralis minor is left intact and level III nodes are not removed. 

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: Which statement best explains how sympathetic stimulation affects the heart?

choices.text: The permeability of the S-A node to sodium decreases
The permeability of the A-V node to sodium decreases
The permeability of the S-A node to potassium increases
There is an increased rate of upward drift of the resting membrane potential of the SA node

questions.solution:
There is an increased rate of upward drift of the resting membrane potential of the S-A node.

During sympathetic stimulation, the permeabilities of the S-A node and the A-V node increase. In addition, the permeability of cardiac muscle to muscle increases, resulting in an increased contractile strength.

Increased permeability of the S-A node to potassium does not occur during sympathetic stimulation.

questions.text: Omalizumab is indicated for which of the following conditions ?
questions.solution:
Omalizumab is indicated for bronchial asthma. It is administered sub-cutaneously every 2-4 weeks and prevents acute exacerbations of asthma.

However, because of it very high cost, it is used only in cases of severe asthma not responding to cortico-steroids and in severe allergic rhinitis.

questions.text: Which of the following anticancer drugs can cause a hypercoagulable state?
questions.solution:
L-asparaginase can cause a hypercoagulable state.

L-asparaginase causes the breakdown of asparagine and thus interferes with protein synthesis. It can inhibit the production of clotting factors, leading to cerebral haemorrhage. It can also inhibit anti-clotting proteins and can lead to cortical vein thrombosis and other hyper-coagulable sates.

questions.text: Amino acid responsible for thioredoxin reductase activation is ____________
questions.solution:
Selenocysteine is responsible for thioredoxin reductase activation.

Selenocysteine is seen in the active site of the following enzymes and proteins:

  • Selenoprotein P
  • Iodothyronine deiodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase
  • Glutathione peroxidase

questions.text: Testicular enlargement in males is the hallmark of SMR stage __________
questions.solution:
Testicular enlargement in males is the hallmark of SMR stage 2. It is the first sign of puberty in males. It is seen at 9.5 years of age.

questions.text: A sample of 100 patients with brain tumours and 100 disease free patients is taken to evaluate the diagnosis by EEG results. EEG test results were positive in 90 patients with brain tumours, and positive in 30 disease free patients.  What is the negative predictive value of EEG test?
questions.solution:
The negative predictive value of EEG test is 87.5%. It is derived as follows:

The contingency table in above case:

  Patients with brain tumours Disease free patients
EEG test Positive 90(a) 30(b)
EEG test Negative 10(c) 70(d)
  • Sensitivity = a/a+c = 90/100 = 90%
  • Specificity = d/d+b = 70/100 = 70%
  • PPV = a/a+b = 90/ 120 = 75%
  • NPV = d/d+c = 70 / 80 = 87.5%

 

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Myocardial necrosis can be best demonstrated by?
questions.solution:
Myocardial necrosis is best demonstrated by Tc99m Pyrophosphate. It binds to the calcium in the necrotic tissue and generates a ‘hot spot’ on the scan. Thallium 201 and Tc99m Tetrofosmin are also used for detecting myocardial perfusion.

A MUGA acquisition scan (also called equilibrium radionuclide angiogram or blood pool scan) is a noninvasive diagnostic test used to evaluate ventricular function.

questions.text:
Sputum from asthma patient may show :
a) Numerous eosinophils
b) Curschmann’s spirals
c) Charcot –Leyden crystals
questions.solution:
Characteristics finding in sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage specimen of an asthma patient is Curschmann spirals, which may result from extrusion of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles. Also present are eosinophils and eosinophil protein galectin-10 forms Charcot Leyden crystals.

Other characteristic histologic findings of asthma, collectively called airway remodelling include:

  • Thickening of airway wall
  • Subbasement membrane fibrosis(due to deposition of collagen I and III)
  • Increased vascularity 
  • An increase in the size of the submucosal glands and number of airway goblet cells.
  • Hypertrophy or hyperplasia of bronchial wall muscle.

Airway remodelling also adds an irreversible component to the obstructive disease.

questions.text: Culture of a boy with skin ulcer on leg  reveals beta hemolysis. Cultures from school children with sore throat some days back also revealed beta hemolysis. What is similarity between both ?

choices.text: Mec A is related to it

questions.solution:
The carbohydrate C antigen is same in both cases. Carbohydrate C antigen is group specific i.e. beta haemolytic group A streptococci have same C antigen. (Lancefield grouping)

Option b and d:

Strains causing skin infection and throat infection are different and belong to different M serotypes. (Griffith typing)

Option a:

Mec A gene is found in bacterial cells and is responsible for resistance to antibiotics such as methicillin, penicillin, tetracycline and other pencillin like antibiotics. The most commonly known carrier of the mec A gene is MRSA.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman had severe blood loss during delivery 2-days ago. Her current hemoglobin is 5 gm/dL and reticulocyte count is 9%. What is her corrected reticulocyte count?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the corrected reticulocyte count is 3.

It is given by the following formula:

Corrected reticulocyte count = Reticulocyte count × (patient's hemoglobin or hematocrit ⁄ standard hemoglobin or hematocrit)

So, in this case, the corrected reticulocyte count = 9×5/15  = 9/3  = 3

This formula corrects for hemoglobin. It will show you if the patient is making enough reticulocytes for the degree of anemia present. As the hemoglobin drops, reticulocytes increase from the normal range of 0.5–2.0%.

The standard reference range of hemoglobin concentration in females is 12-15 g/dl. Accordingly, in this scenario, corrected reticulocyte count would range between 3-3.75%. So, the best answer to this question remains option C.

Absolute reticulocyte count is the percentage of red cells that are reticulocytes (normal is about 0.5 – 2.0%). However, it does not reflect the fact that as the hemoglobin drops, there should be more reticulocytes, percentage-wise (for example, at a hemoglobin of 5, you should have a much higher percentage of reticulocytes than you should at a hemoglobin of 10). To take this into account, we use corrected reticulocyte count.

Reticulocyte Index = Corrected reticulocyte count / maturation factor

This corrects for the longer life span of prematurely released reticulocytes in the blood which is a phenomenon of increased red blood cell production.

Hematocrit Maturation factor
≥ 35% 1.0
35% > Hct ≥ 25% 1.5
25% > Hct ≥ 20% 2.0
< 20% 2.5

questions.text: Which of the following statement regarding visceral pain signals is correct?

choices.text: They are transmitted along sensory fibers that course mainly with sympathetic nerves in the abdomen and thorax
They are not stimulated by ischemia in visceral organs
They are transmitted only by the lightly myelinated delta-type A sensory fibers

questions.solution:
Visceral pain signals are transmitted along sensory fibers that course mainly with sympathetic nerves in the abdomen and thorax.

Visceral pain signals from structures in the abdomen and thorax travel toward the spinal cord in association with fibers of sympathetic system.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about phototherapy in neonatal jaundice?

choices.text: 460- 490nm is the most effective wavelength for neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinaemia
Porphyria is a contraindication to phototherapy
Irreversible structural isomerisation is the most important mechanism for phototherapy
Phototherapy should be discontinued in a newborn with bronze baby syndrome

questions.solution:
Phototherapy can be continued in a newborn with bronze baby syndrome, if needed.  Bronze baby syndrome refers to dark, grayish brown skin discoloration seen in some infants undergoing phototherapy.

Other options:

  • 460- 490nm is the most effective wavelength for neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinaemia.
  • Irreversible structural isomerisation is the most important mechanism for phototherapy. There is formation of lumirubin from native bilirubin that can be excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state. Other mechanisms include reversible photoisomerization reaction and photo oxidation.
  • Porphyria is a contraindication to phototherapy.

questions.text:
True statment regarding addictive  gaming  behaviour:
a) It will come into effect from Jan 1, 2022
b) For its diagnosis, a behaviour pattern must be of sufficient severity to result in significant impairment for at least 6 months.
c)It exhibits somatisation, anxiety , behavioural changes and  sleep disturbances with the absence of depressive symptoms.
Options-
questions.solution:
The World Health Organisation (WHO) has classified gaming addiction as mental health disorder in its International Classification of Diseases (ICD) 11 recently which will come into effect from Jan 1,2022.

WHO described the addiction as a pattern of persistent or recurrent gaming behaviour that becomes so extensive it takes precedence over other life interests.

The classification is aimed at alerting health professionals and systems to the existence of this condition and ensuring that people suffering from these conditions can get appropriate help.

Gaming disorder characteristics:

  1. The gaming behaviour takes precedence over other activities to the extent that other activities are pushed to the periphery.
  2. The condition leads to significant distress and impairment in personal, familial, social, educational or occupational functioning.
  3. Gaming disorder can lead to disturbed sleep patterns, diet problems and deficiency in physical activities.
  4. Abnormal gaming behaviour should be in evidence over a period of at least 12 months for a diagnosis to be assigned but added that period might be shortened if symptoms are severe.
  5. Symptoms include:
    • impaired control over gaming (frequency, intensity, duration)
    • increased priority given to gaming
    • continuation or escalation of gaming despite negative consequence.

questions.text: Malaria vaccine RTS,S/AS01 is effective against_____________
questions.solution: Malaria vaccine RTS,S/AS01 is effective against P. Falciparum. Phase 3 trial of this vaccine has already been completed. There is a positive scientific opinion about its risk benefit balance and a phase 4 trial is under evaluation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Mendelson syndrome?

choices.text: Gastric pH<4 is a risk factor
Once suspected, patient should be positioned upright
Promotility drugs can be used to decrease the incidence

questions.solution:
Commonly used agents to decrease the incidence of Mendelson syndrome include promotility drugs (e.g., metoclopramide), H2-receptor antagonists, nonparticulate antacids (e.g., Bicitra).

Mendelson's syndrome is chemical pneumonitis or aspiration pneumonitis caused by aspiration during anesthesia, especially during pregnancy.

The risk factors include:

  • Gastric volume is greater than 25 mL (0.4 mL/kg)
  • Gastric pH is less than 2.5

Measures to reduce the incidence of aspiration:

  • Administration of nonparticulate antacids like 30ml sodium citrate 30-45 minutes prior to intubation.
  • H2 receptor antagonists like intravenous ranitidine 50mg and/or
  • Metoclopramide  10mg 1-2 hours prior to induction

Management of intraoperative aspiration:

  • Once suspected, patient is positioned in trendelenberg (head down tilt) or lateral so that gastric contents drain out of the mouth instead of into the trachea.
  • Suctioning of pharynx and trachea (if possible).
  • Intubation and the institution of positive end-expiratory pressure if hypoxic.
  • Bronchoscopy, pulmonary lavage and broad-spectrum antibiotics if particulate aspiration.

Maternal mortality associated with this aspiration pneumonitis is 5-15%

questions.text: The instrument given below is used to measure____________
questions.solution:
The instrument given is sling pschyrometer, which is used to measure humidity.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

questions.text: In forming 3D structure of protein following factors help except_______________
questions.solution:
Peptide bond helps in primary structure of protein (not 3D structure) 

3D structure of protein:

  • Amino acid sequence determines the tertiary structure of proteins.
  • Interaction of polypeptides also helps the  three dimensional structure of protein.
  • Chaperones helps in protein folding and hence are invoved in the three dimensional structure.
  • Side chains help in the formation of bonds involved in tertiary structure of proteins.

questions.text: Which of the following types of microcalcification poses the maximum risk of malignancy?
questions.solution:
Cluster microcalcification poses the greatest risk of indicating a malignancy and Diffuse microcalcification poses the least.

Related Pearl: Types of microcalcification indicating malignancy

In decreasing order of risk of malignancy-

  • Cluster microcalcification (maximum risk)
  • Linear microcalcification
  • Segmental microcalcification
  • Diffuse microcalcification (minimum risk)

questions.text: Which of the following nuclear staining  indicates antibodies to histones?
questions.solution:
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining indicates antibodies to histones

Most common widely used method for detecting ANAs(antinuclear antibodies) is indirect immunofluoresence.

 

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about radioactive iodine?

choices.text: Iodine 123 has a half-life of 15 hours
Iodine 131 is used for ablation of thyroid
Iodine 131 has a half-life of 8 days
Iodine 123 is used for thyroid scans

questions.solution:
Iodine 123 has a half-life of 13 hours and Half-lives of other radioactive iodine.

  • Iodine 131 has a half-life of 8 days
  • Iodine 125 has a half-life of 60 days
  • Iodine 124 has a half-life of 4.18 days

Iodine 131 is used for destruction of thyroid tissues due to the production of beta rays. Iodine 123 has only gamma activity and is used as a nuclear imaging tracer.

Option C has been revised to "Iodine 131 has a half-life of 8 days" . Previously, Option C had incorrectly stated "Iodine 131 has a half-life of 8 hours" The explanation has been revised to reflect the same.

questions.text: Zinc supplementation for diarrhoea management of 5month old child should be _______
questions.solution:
Zinc supplementation for diarrhoea management of 5month old child should be 10mg/day.

Zinc dosage: (for 10 to 14 days)

  • Age <6 months – 10 mg/day
  • Age >6 months –  20 mg/day

Zinc supplementation in diarrhoea: It reduces mortality and hospital admission. In addition it improves diarrhoea recovery rates and reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials.

questions.text: What are the components of the modified Goeckerman regimen used for the management of patients with psoriasis?
questions.solution:
The modified Goeckerman regimen used in the management of patients with psoriasis comprises UVB plus coal tar.

Goeckerman regimen was invented for the treatment of mild to moderate psoriasis. Although the mode of action of the therapy is unknown, it is found to be associated with:

  • Decreased serum levels of inflammatory cytokines
  • Significant reduction in PASI - Psoriasis Assessment of Severity Index
  • Improvements in anxiety, depression, and quality of life scores
  • The longest remission times are seen when compared to any other treatment for psoriasis with a mean of 22 months

In this therapy, the application of crude coal tar (CCT) for 5 hours/day, is followed by exposure to narrow-band UVB (NB-UVB).

The short-term side effects seen are folliculitis and phototoxic reactions.

This treatment is almost obsolete now. Pre-treatment with acitretin before starting the Goeckerman regimen decreases the number of days needed for the lesions to clear. But, if a patient does not respond to this regimen, the diagnosis of psoriasis should be reconfirmed by a skin biopsy.

Management of psoriasis includes:

  • Topical treatment:
    • corticosteroids - most common
    • vitamin D analogs like calcitriol
    • topical retinoids
    • immunomodulators like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus
    • coal tar
    • keratolytic like salicylic acid and urea
  • Intralesional steroids to resistant plaques
  • Light therapy - UVB, PUVA
  • Systemic therapies like methotrexate, cyclosporine, and mycophenolate mofetil
  • Biological therapies:
    • TNF inhibitors: Infliximab, Etanercept, Adalimumab
    • IL12/ 23 inhibitor: Ustekinumab
    • Selective IL-23 inhibitor: Tildrakizumab
    • IL-17 inhibitors: Secukinumab, Brodalumab
    • Phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitors: Apremilast

Complications of psoriasis include secondary infection, poor cosmetic appearance, risk of lymphoma, and psoriatic arthritis.

Other option:

UVB plus anthralin combination is known as Ingram regimen.

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not useful for controlling epistaxis caused by over anticoagulation?
questions.solution:
Tranexamic acid, an antifibrinolytic agent, has not been shown to help in cases of over anticoagulated patients.   

Agents that work include Fresh frozen plasma, clotting factor extracts, and vitamin K. Vitamin K takes more than 6 hours to work, and it can delay anticoagulation for 7 days after warfarin is started.  

If the international normalized ratio is greater than 4, the warfarin should be stopped, and fresh frozen plasma should be given.  Clotting factor extracts should be given with extreme caution because of the risk of thromboembolic complications.

questions.text: Which of the following SERMs is useful for the treatment of osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Raloxifene is a SREM useful for treatment of osteoporosis.

Raloxifene is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM) with oestrogen agonistic action on bone and antagonistic action on breast and endometrium.

It is therefore the preferred drug for the treatment and prevention of post-menopausal osteoporosis.

Major adverse effect of this drug is increased risk of thromboembolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of benign murmur?
questions.solution:
Diastolic murmur (always organic and rarely benign) is not a characteristic of benign murmur.

A Benign murmur is one without structural heart disease. It is also known as Innocent, Functional, Normal or Flow murmur

  • The triad in favour of innocence of a murmur is:
    • No suspicious history suggestive of organic heart disease
    • Characteristic innocent murmur
    • No additional clinical findings in favour of organic heart disease
  • Characteristic of innocent murmurs:
    • Should not be more than grade 3
    • Never louder at apex
    • Never radiates to neck
    • Mostly systolic
    • Never diastolic
    • Never associated with click
    • No clinical evidence of any chamber enlargement
  • Examples of innocent murmur: The normal murmurs of childhood are composed of five systolic and two continuous types but are never solely diastolic :
    • Still’s murmur
    • Aortic systolic murmur
    • Innocent pulmonary flow murmur
    • Pulmonary branch murmur
    • Supraclavicular murmur
    • Venous hum
    • Mammary souffle
    • Functional murmur in adult

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about apoptosis?

choices.text: There is enzymatic digestion of cellular contents
It is associated with adjacent inflammation

questions.solution:
The plasma membrane remains intact in apoptosis.

Apoptosis literally means falling-off in Greek. It is a pathway of programmed cell death.

Apoptotic cells break up into fragments called apoptotic bodies. These apoptotic bodies have intact plasma membrane but altered structures. Hence, they are subjected to phagocytosis without eliciting inflammation.

Necrosis is an unprogrammed form of cell death that includes:

  • Enzymatic digestion
  • Adjacent inflammation
  • Karyolysis

Related Pearl: Necrosis vs Apoptosis

Apoptosis

Active process

questions.text: Priority actions in national health policy 2017, includes ______________
questions.solution:
Priority actions in national health policy 2017, includes all of the above i.e swachh bharat abhiyan, yatri suraksha and nirbhaya nari.

National Health Policy, 2017

The draft of the policy from 2015 was passed by the government in 2017 and is called the National Health Policy, 2017.

Specific quantitative goals and objectives:

   These can be divided into three broad components

  1. Health Status and Programme Impact:
    • Increase life expectancy at birth from 67.5 to 70 by 2025
    • Reduce Infant Mortality Rate to 28 by 2019
    • Reduce Neonatal Mortality to 16 and still birth rate to single digit by 2025
    • Reduce Maternal Mortality Ratio(MMR) from current levels to 100 by 2020
    • Achieve elimination of lymphatic filariasis by 2017

  2. Health Systems Performance:

    • Increase utilization of public health facilities by 50% from current levels by 2025
    • Antenatal care coverage to be sustained above 90%
    • More than 90% of the newborn are fully immunized by one year of age by 2025.
    • Access to safe water and sanitation to all by 2020 (Swachh Bharat Mission)
  3. Health Systems Financing:
    • Increase health expenditure to 2.5% of GDP by 2025

    • Increase State sector health spending to > 8% of their budget by 2020.

 

Priority actions to improve environment for health

  • Swachh Bharat Abhiyan
  • Balanced healthy diets and regular exercise
  • Addressing tobacco, alcohol and substance abuse
  • Yatri Suraksha to reduce death due to accidents
  • Nirbhaya Nari for action against gender violence
  • Reduced stress and improved safety in work places
  • Reducing indoor and outdoor air pollution

Other provisions in this policy include the NEET exam for UG, increased thrust in HIV-centered communities for treatment and diagnosis, establishment of nursing schools in every district and food safety.

questions.text: Blood gas measurements are obtained in a resting patient who is breathing room air. The patient has an arterial content of 19ml O2 /min with a PO2  of 95. The mixed venous O2 is 4 ml O2 /100 ml blood. Which of the following condition does the patient have?

choices.text: An increase in physiologic dead space

questions.solution:
The patient has a low cardiac output. A low cardiac output would require a greater extraction of O2 to the tissues, resulting in a decreased mixed venous content (normal 60-80%; 4% in the above patient).

Other options:

With a PO2 of 95 and an arterial content of 19 ml O2 /dl on room air suggest the patient has no issues with V/Q ratio or pulmonary oedema and has a normal Hb concentration.

questions.text: Which organism causing relapsing fever is transmitted by the following vector?
questions.solution:
The vector shown above is body louse pediculus humanus humanus. It transmits the spirochete Borrelia recurrentis which causes Louse-borne relapsing fever (LBRF).

The disease can be severe and death occurs in 10% to 40% of cases in the absence of appropriate treatment, and in 2-5% of treated patients. A potentially severe or fatal Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction can be induced by antibiotic treatment.

Other options:

  • Borrelia duttoni and borrelia parkeri is associated with tick borne relapsing fever.
  • Borrelia burgdorferi is associated with lyme disease.

questions.text: Platelet transfusion must be completed in how many hours after puncturing the bag?
questions.solution:
Platelets must be administered within 4 hours, once the blood bag is opened by puncturing one of the sealed ports.

Distinction has to be made between the time required to transfuse a bag of platelet(around 30 mins) and the time before which a bag of platelets must be transfused for it to be safe(4 hours).

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic disease extending to all genital structures should be classified as ________
questions.solution:
Gestational trophoblastic disease extending to all genital structures should be classified as stage II.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

  • Older age
  • β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • Uterine size that is large-forgestational age
  • Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm
  • Slow decline in β-hCG levels
  • Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

questions.text: Considering the image given, the most common site of airway collapse in obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS) is ________
questions.solution:
The soft palate (B in the image) is the most common site for airway collapse in OSAHS. Other sites include the base of tongue (A), lateral pharyngeal wall (C) and/or epiglottis (D).

Note:

OSAHS may be particularly severe in the supine position, due to gravitational forces, and during REM sleep as the neuromuscular output to muscles is particularly low.

questions.text:
Which of the following parameters are used for assessment of quality of proteins?
1. Amino acid score
2. Net protein utilization
3. Protein energy ratio
questions.solution:
Both amino acid score and net protein utilization are used for assessment of protein quality.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: The similarity between Vitamin C and Vitamin K is ____________

choices.text: Both help in conversion of proline to hydroxyproline
Both help in post translational modification
Both are involved in coagulation cascade

questions.solution:
The similarity between Vitamin C and Vitamin K is Both help in post translational modification.

 Vitamin C assists the post-translational modification of collagen by reducing iron in the participating enzymes, lysyl hydroxylase and prolyl hydroxylase . Modified/mature collagen undergoes important protein-protein interaction yielding a unique structure that is essential for its functions .

The vitamin K-dependent carboxylase carries out the posttranslational modification of specific glutamate residues in proteins to gamma-carboxy glutamic acid (Gla) in the presence of reduced vitamin K, molecular oxygen, and carbon dioxide.The modification has a wide range of physiological implications, including hemostasis, bone calcification, and signal transduction.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for scabies is _______
questions.solution:
Permethrin cream (5%) is the treatment of choice for scabies. It is rinsed off after 8-12 hours. It is safe and well-tolerated but often requires a second application after one week.

Benzyl benzoate (25%) ointment requires to be rinsed off after 24 hours and is contraindicated in pregnant women and children.

Crotamiton (10%) ointment is often used on scabies nodules in children but has questionable efficacy.

Malathion is not used for the treatment of scabies however it may be used to treat lice infestation.

questions.text: Which of the following takes the least amount of time till peak drug effect following a bolus dose?
questions.solution:
Alfentanil takes 1.4 minutes till peak drug effect. Morphine takes the maximum amount of time, about 19min.

Propofol and Thiopental, both take about 1.6 min till peak dose effect.

questions.text: A boy has staining teeth and raised coproporphyrin I levels and increased risk of photosensitivity. The enzyme deficient is_____________
questions.solution:

Features of congential erythropoietic porphyria(CEP):

  • It presents shortly after birth or in utero as non immune hydrops. It can present with severe cutaneous photosensitivity.
  • There are porphyrin deposits in teeth and bones, giving it a brownish colour and a reddish fluorescence of teeth when illuminated with long UV light.
  • Uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulate in bone marrow, erythrocyte, plasma, urine and feces.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: PO2 (in mm Hg) in skeletal muscle during exercise ?
questions.solution:
PO2 in skeletal muscle during exercise can be as low as 1 to 3 mm Hg. This is mainly due to the compression of blood vessels supplying the muscle during muscle contraction. Fortunately, myoglobin in the muscle acts as reservoir of O2 and enhances its diffusion during exercise.

Skeletal muscle blood flow during exercise:

  • At rest, skeletal muscles receive blood flow of 2-4 mL/100g/min. But during exercise the value increases by more than 20 times to 80 mL/100g/min.
  • This increase is mainly because of:
    • Accumulation of local metabolites that cause vasodilation
    • Opening up of new capillaries during exercise

Redistribution of blood flow in the body:

  • Tremendous increase in skeletal muscle flow is made possible by redistribution of blood flow.
  • Sympathetic, noradrenergic vasoconstriction occurs in two important vascular beds:
    • Renal circulation
    • Splanchnic blood flow
  • Vasoconstriction in renal and splanchnic system diverts their blood to the exercising muscle
  • Cutaneous blood flow increases during sustained activities to dissipate the heat generated during exercise
  • Coronary blood flow increases by more than four times than normal
  • Cerebral blood flow remains largely unchanged

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the Meyer Overton rule?

choices.text: Potency of gases as anaesthetics was strongly correlated with their solubility in water
Enantiomers of anaesthetics have the same potency as anaesthetics
This is also called the unitary theory of anaesthesia
All of the above are true

questions.solution:
The Meyer Overton rule is also called the unitary theory of anaesthesia.

They observed that the potency of gases as anaesthetics was strongly correlated with their solubility in olive oil, not water.

A final deviation from the Meyer–Overton rule is the observation that enantiomers of anaesthetics differ in their potency as anaesthetics.

This MCQ has been revised to reflect the correct answer.Previously, The answer was incorrectly marked as "Potency of gases as anaesthetics was strongly correlated with their solubility in water". However, this statement is False and the only True statement is "The Meyer Overton rule is also called the unitary theory of anaesthesia"

questions.text: Which of the following statements about feedback control system is incorrect?

choices.text: Most control systems of the body act by negative feedback
Positive feedback usually promotes stability in a system
Generation of nerve actions potentials involves positive feedback
Feed-forward control is important in regulating muscle activity

questions.solution:
Positive feedback in a system generally promotes instability, rather than stability, and in some cases even death. For this reason, positive feedback, is often called a vicious cycle.

However, in some instances, positive feedback can be beneficial. One example is the nerve action potential where stimulation of the nerve membrane causes a slight leakage of sodium that causes more opening of sodium channels and this continues until an explosion of sodium entering the interior of nerve fiber creates the action potential.

Feed-forward control is used to apprise the brain whether a muscle movement is performed correctly. If not, the brain corrects the feed-forward signals that it sends to the muscle the next time the movement is required. This mechanism is often called adaptive control.

Most control systems of the body act by negative feedback.

questions.text: Gingival biopsy is useful in the diagnosis of_____________
questions.solution:
Gingival biopsy is useful in the diagnosis of amyloidosis.

The diagnosis of amyloidosis depends on the histologic demonstration of amyloid deposits in tissues. The most common site biopsied are the kidney, when renal manifestations present or rectal or gingival tissuses in patients suspected of having systemic amyloidosis.

For other options :     

  • Sarcoidosis: Transbronchial biopsy is usually diagnostic.      
  • Histoplasmosis: Oropharyngeal ulcer biopsy is usually diagnostic, biopsy from pulmomary lesions and lymphnodes is also diagnostic. .

questions.text: A model cell with three different transporters (X, Y and Z) and a resting membrane potential of -75 millivolts is shown in the given figure. Consider the intracellular and extracellular concentrations of all three ions to be typical of a normal cell. Which of the following best describe transporter Y?
questions.solution:
Secondary active transport best describes the transporter Y.

In a normal cell, intracellular concentrations of sodium, calcium, and chloride are less than the extracellular concentrations, whereas potassium has a higher intracellular concentration compared with its extracellular concentration.

The figure shows that transporter Y moves sodium down its concentration gradient into the cell and moves calcium against its concentration gradient out of the cell. The energy required to move calcium ions against their concentration gradient is supplied by the sodium concentration gradient (which was supplied by ATP) and is a typical example of secondary active transport.

Transporter X in the figure moves both potassium and sodium against their concentration gradients, requiring use of ATP at the pump, and is a example of primary active transport.

Transporter Z suggests that chloride can move in either direction across the cell membrane but only by simple diffusion through the water-filled membrane channel.

questions.text: A traveller who was lost in a desert during his travel could not drink water for one day. He started to have symptoms of dehydration. Which change would you expect to find in this person?

choices.text: Increased water permeability of the ascending loop of Henle
Increased water permeability of the collecting duct

questions.solution:
Increased water permeability of the collecting duct will be expected in a dehydrated person deprived of water for 24 hours.

Dehydration due to water deprivation causes an increase in extracellular osmolality. This in turn signals the osmoreceptors and stimulates the increase in the plasma levels of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). This leads to increased permeability of water in the late distal tubules, and cortical and medullary collecting ducts. This further results in the formation of a small volume of concentrated urine, thereby correcting the extracellular fluid osmolality. 

The increased ADH increases the water permeability in the collecting ducts but the ascending loop of Henle is relatively impermeable to water. This low permeability is not altered by water deprivation or increased levels of ADH.

Related Pearl: Water transport along nephron

Segment

Mechanism of Water Reabsorption

Proximal tubule(67%)

Osmosis, AQ 1

Loop of Henle (15%)

Descending thin limb only; aquaporin 1 channels

Early distal convoluted tubule(0%)

No water reabsorption

Late distal tubule and collecting duct (8-17%)

Passive(aquaporin-2) under the influence of ADH

questions.text: Which of the following is an immune checkpoint inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Durvalumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It is an antagonist of PD-L1 which is a protein-ligand that is present on antigen-presenting cells, T cells, B cells, and some cancer cells.

Immune checkpoint inhibitors inhibit proteins that help the cancer cells evade the immune response. When these proteins are blocked, the brake on the immune system is released and T cells are able to kill cancer cells more efficiently.

Durvalumab is approved for use in metastatic urothelial and Merkel cell cancer. The FDA approved Durvalumab in combination with etoposide and either carboplatin or cisplatin as first-line treatment of patients with extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer.

Other PD-L1 inhibitors include:

  • Atezolizumab
  • Avelumab
  • Durvalumab

questions.text: Clavipectoral fascia forms which of the following ligaments?
questions.solution:
The Gerdy's ligament or the suspensory ligament of the axilla, is a ligament that connects the clavipectoral fascia to the axillary fascia and thereby gives shape to the axilla.

Broad ligament is a fold of peritoneum that attaches the pelvis to the ovaries and uterus.

Suspensory ligaments of cooper are condensations of connective tissue that help in maintaining the shape of the breast.

The cardinal ligaments(lateral or transverse cervical or Mackenrodt's ligaments) are situated along the inferior border of the broad ligament and continue from the side of cervix and lateral fornix of vagina. They contain the uterine artery and uterine veins.

questions.text: The following cells seen in the lymph node are indicative of
questions.solution:
The given slide is pathognomonic for measles. This is a slide of a lymph node biopsy showing a Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell with large grapelike clusters of inclusion bodies.

The lymphoid organs typically have marked follicular hyperplasia, large germinal centers, and randomly distributed multinucleate giant cells (Warthin-Finkeldey cells) which have eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

These are pathognomonic of measles and are also found in the lung and sputum.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysms?

choices.text: Migration of smooth muscle into the sac
Absence of intimal elastic lamina in the sac
Deposition of mucoid material in the media
Low-grade inflammation of the vessel wall

questions.solution:
The true statement about the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysms is the absence of intimal elastic interna in the sac.

Saccular (or berry) aneurysm is the most common type of intracranial aneurysm, most often occurring in the anterior circulation of the circle of Willis. Rupture of this aneurysm is the most common cause of spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage.

The following factors are implicated in the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysm:

  • Genetic factors: Increased incidence in first-degree relatives
  • Associated syndromes: Increased incidence in individuals with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, neurofibromatosis type 1, Marfan syndrome, etc
  • Predisposing factors: Increased incidence in cigarette smokers and individuals with hypertension

The aneurysmal sac is made up of thickened hyalinized intima and a covering of adventitia. The absence of smooth muscle and intimal elastic lamina in the sac suggests that these aneurysms are developmental anomalies. Atheromatous plaques, calcification, thrombi, or prior hemorrhage may be present within the aneurysm.  

Rupture usually occurs at the apex of the sac. It is often associated with a sudden increase in intracranial pressure, such as when straining during defecation or sexual stimulation. Patients complain of an acute excruciating headache and loss of consciousness. The prognosis worsens with each episode.
