questions.text: The degree of prolapse shown in the image given below is _______
questions.solution: The image shows external os lying at the level of introitus. Hence it is second degree uterine prolapse.

questions.text: Dried blood drop of an infant can be used to know___________
questions.solution:
Dried blood group of an infant can be used to know inborn errors of metabolism with help of tandem mass spectrometry.

It can be used to screen blood samples from newborns for presence and concentration of amino acids, fatty acids and other metabolites. Abnormalties in metabolite levels can serve as a diagnostic indication for a variety of genetic disorders, such as phenylketonuria, ethylmalonic encephalopathy and glutaric academia type 1.

questions.text: Polysomnography contains all of the following except__________
questions.solution:
Polysomnography contains all of the above except arterial Pco2 measurement.

Polysomnography is used to study sleep and its associated phenomena. It is usually the preferred method in sleep research centers. It consists of the following:

  • Continuous EEG recording, from occipital and parietal leads
  • Electro-oculography- to record eye movements
  • Electromyography- for muscle potential and its activities
  • ECG
  • Multiple sleep latency tests- repeated measures of time taken to sleep
  • Nasal-oral airflow, respiratory effort, oxyhemoglobin saturation, and leg movements during sleep are measured.

questions.text: Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm are seen in________
questions.solution:
Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm are seen in Langerhans cells.

They are pentalaminar tubules often with a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket like appearance, which contain protein langerin. Although a part of normal Langerhans histology they also provide a mechanism to differentiate Langerhans cell histocytes from other proliferative cells.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented with fatigue and weight loss. On examination, pallor and splenomegaly were noted. Peripheral blood smear examination findings are shown in the image. Which of the following BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors is not a first-line agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the peripheral smear findings (increased WBCs with myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms), is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). Bosutinib is approved for use in this condition only for resistant and/or intolerant cases and not in newly diagnosed cases.

Agents that can be used as first-line for CML are:

  • Imatinib
  • Dasatinib
  • Nilotinib 

Dasatinib and nilotinib can be used in newly diagnosed cases of CML, that are found to be imatinib-resistant.

questions.text: A study was conducted on the effectiveness of a keto diet for weight loss. Weight of the participants was measured before starting the keto diet and after 1 month of the keto diet.  Which of the following is the most appropriate test to test the statistical significance of the change in weight?
questions.solution:
Since the effect of keto diet is checked on the same individuals, before and after the keto diet, therefore the test used is paired t test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Fetal anomaly which can be detected earliest by ultrasonography is ________________
questions.solution:
Anencephaly can be detected earliest by ultrasonography.

Anencephaly: It is characterized by absence of the cranium and telencephalic structures, with the skullbase and orbits covered only by angiomatous stroma. It can be diagnosed in the late first trimester, and with adequate visualization, virtually all cases may be diagnosed in the second trimester.

Related Pearl: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

  • The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.
  • The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.
  • Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)
  • CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy
  • CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.
  • The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a normal finding in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Image B shows buphthalmos, which is not a normal finding in a newborn. It is suggestive of congenital glaucoma and thus it should be investigated. The sclera and cornea are more elastic in early childhood and an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP), therefore, leads to an expansion of the globe and the development of buphthalmos (ox eye).

Image A shows mongolian spots, and image C shows erythema toxicum. These both are normal findings.

Normal findings in a newborn:

  • Erythema toxicum – small white papules on an erythematous base which is usually present on the face, trunk and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week.
  • Conjunctival haemorrhage
  • Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back.
  • Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.
  • Vaginal bleeding in newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.
  • Hymenal tags
  • Physiological phimosis

questions.text: Syncytium formation is a property of_______
questions.solution:
Syncytium formation is a property of measles virus. It is a cytopathic effect.

Paramyxoviruses like measles virus (MV) infections are initiated by the attachment of the virus to the host cell by the haemagglutinin (H) glycoprotein, whereas penetration into the cell is mediated by the interaction of the fusion (F) glycoprotein with the cell membrane.

In the later stages of infection the newly synthesized glycoproteins accumulate at the cell membrane resulting in fusion with the neighbouring cells to produce syncytia. Thus infection can pass from cell to cell without the necessity of producing complete virus particles.

Cytopathic effect: The morphological changes in cultured cells in which the organisms grow. These changes can be readily observed by microscopic examination of the cultures.

Virus Cytopathic effect
Enterovirus Crenation of cells and degeneration of the entire cell sheet
Measels virus Syncytium formation
Herpes virus Focal degeneration
Adenovirus Large granular clump resembling bunches of grapes
SV 40 Cytoplasmic vacuolation

questions.text: During research on male contraceptives, a group of scientists was studying the blood-testis barrier.  This barrier is located between:
questions.solution:
The blood-testis barrier is located between Sertoli cells and Sertoli cells.

Sertoli cells are linked by tight junctions, the strongest intercellular barrier in the body. This arrangement forms the blood-testes barrier.

Important functions of the blood testes barrier are:

  • It prevents the passing of large molecules from interstitial tissue and basal compartment to the tubular lumen.
  • It helps in maintaining the composition of the tubular fluid.
  • It protects the developing sperms from immunological attack and blood borne noxious agents.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Moraxella catarrhalis?

choices.text: An uncommon cause of COPD exacerbation

questions.solution:
Moraxella catarrhalis is a DNAse positive gram-negative diplococcus. It is the second most common bacterial cause of COPD exacerbations (after H. influenzae). It can also cause otitis media, sinusitis, tracheobronchitis, and pneumonia. 

It differs from pathogenic Neisseria as:

  • It does not ferment any carbohydrates - Asaccharolytic
  • Gives a positive tributyrin hydrolysis test.
  • Shows positive DNAse test.

Angular conjunctivitis is caused by Moraxella lacunata, which is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacteria.

Treatment is with oral amoxicillin and clauvulanic acid.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with progressive ataxia and symptoms of increased intracranial tension, including headaches and vomiting. MR spectroscopy is performed, as shown below. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy showing a choline peak is diagnostic of glioma. Creatinine levels are decreased on MR spectroscopy in patients with glioma.

MR spectroscopy is a non-invasive means of obtaining metabolic information. The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

Other options:

Option B: Tuberculoma shows a lipid peak in MR spectroscopy.  

Option C: In Canavan disease, there is a marked increase in N-acetyl aspartate. Its concentration decreases with insults to the brain such as neoplasm, infarct, or abscess. N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) which is the most prominent resonance in a proton spectrum, is accepted as a normal neuronal functional marker.

Option D: Increased choline reflects increased membrane synthesis and/or an increased number of cells, as seen in lymphoma. However, lymphomas of the nervous system are very rare and seen in immunodeficient states like HIV.

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought by his mother with growth failure and developmental delay. Laboratory investigations revealed a hemoglobin of  8 g/dL and normal levels of vitamin B12 and B9. His peripheral smear is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing hypersegmented neutrophils with normal vitamin B12 and B9 levels is suggestive of orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is a rare autosomal recessive condition. It occurs due to an error in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine resulting in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine. It is of two types:

  • Type I - deficiency of both orotate phosphoribosyl transferase and OMP decarboxylase (together called UMPsynthase)
  • Type II - deficiency of only orotidylate decarboxylase.

Children clinically present with megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, failure to thrive, developmental delay, and intellectual disability.

Confirmation of the diagnosis requires an assay of the transferase and decarboxylase enzymes in the patient's red blood cells. Anemia responds well to the administration of uridine.

Other options:

Option A: Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia. It is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It usually presents as painful monoarthritis that mainly involves the metatarsophalangeal joints of the first toe.

Option B: Severe combined immune deficiency (SCID) occurs due to a deficiency in adenosine deaminase, an enzyme of purine metabolism. This results in the accumulation of adenosine metabolites. This causes premature cell death of B, T and NK cells. Children with SCID present with recurrent oral candidiasis, failure to thrive, diarrhea and interstitial pneumonitis.

Option D: Copper deficiency is usually seen in a condition called Menkes kinky hair syndrome. Children usually present with intellectual disability, hypocupremia, and decreased circulating ceruloplasmin.

questions.text: A patient presented with a vesicle on his shin. Microscopy with Tzanck smear showed giant cells. The causative agent is:
questions.solution:
Vesicles on the shin and giant cells on Tzanck smear suggest the diagnosis of Herpes zoster.

  • After rupturing the roof of the blister, the floor is scraped blade, and material is transferred onto a microscopic slide and fixed.
  • Slides are stained with Giemsa, Wright’s stain, or toluidine blue and examined under the microscope:

questions.text: True statement about dezocine is ?

choices.text: It is slower acting than morphine
It is less potent than morphine

questions.solution:
Dezocine doesn’t increase plasma histamine and produces less hypotension than morphine or pentazocine.

Dezocine is slightly more potent than and faster acting opioid than morphine with a similar duration of action.

It is active at Mu receptors and side effects are similar to those of morphine.

Dezocine is effective for moderate to severe pain but can cause myocardial depression.

questions.text: Early head control with bobbing motion can be seen in a baby at the age of?
questions.solution:
Early head control with bobbing motion can be seen in a baby at the age of 3 months. Regarding head steadiness:

  • Up till 2 months of age, there is a significant head lag when a baby is pulled to sit.
  • At 3 months, head lag is partially compensated but still present; The baby attains early head control with bobbing motion and sits with back rounded.
  • At 4 months, there is no head lag when pulled to sit and the baby sits with full truncal support.

questions.text: Identify the mode in USG.
questions.solution:
The USG image represents the M-mode used for echocardiography. Echo intensity is represented as brightness and a trace is swept across the screen so that the x-axis represents time.

Ultrasonography is a versatile imaging modality known for its portability and safety, particularly as it does not involve radiation exposure. As the safest radiological investigation for pregnancy, it provides crucial information without posing any risks to the mother or fetus, making it indispensable in obstetric care. 

Different modes in USG and its uses are as follows:

  1. A (amplitude) mode: Used in ophthalmology and orbital biometry (option A).
  2. B (brightness) mode: Used for all routine applications, with brightness encoded as grayscale value (option B).
  3. M (motion) mode: In echocardiography. 

HIFU (high-intensity focussed USG) is a therapeutic application of USG. It is useful for the treatment of fibroids. HIFU exploits the thermal effects of high-powered, tightly focused ultrasound beams so that very small target tissues can be heated and coagulated.

The image below depicts a duplex scan, which is a combination of B-mode imaging and pulsed Doppler data acquisition.

Doppler ultrasound (option D) is used in diagnosing peripheral arterial disease. It uses a handheld Doppler ultrasound probe placed at an arterial site. A normal arterial wave has a triphasic signal. A triphasic wave has three waveforms consisting of a sharp systolic wave with a forward uprise and fall, a second wave with reverse flow occurring in diastole, and the last wave with a forward flow taking place during diastole. 

Doppler ultrasound can detect moving blood. However, it does not provide information on whether the blood flow is sufficient for the maintenance of limb viability. 

The image below shows triphasic signal on doppler ultrasound:

questions.text: Which type of oral candidiasis does not present with white patch?
questions.solution:
Chronic erythematous (atrophic) candidiasis appears as a red, raw-looking lesion instead of a white patch seen in all other types.

Some sources consider denture related stomatitis, angular stomatitis, median rhomboid glossitis and anti-biotic induced stomatitis as subtypes of erythematous candidiasis, since these lesions are commonly erythematous/atrophic.

It may precede the formation of a psuedomembrane, be left when the membrane is removed, or arise de-novo.

On the tongue, there is loss of the lingual papillae, leaving a smooth area on the tongue.

Usually occurs on dorsum of the tongue on patients taking long-term corticosteroids or antibiotics, but occasionally it can occur after only a few days of using a topical antibiotics. This is usually termed ‘antibiotic sore mouth/stomatitis’ because it is painful as well as red.

Chronic erythematous candidiasis is usually associated with denture wearing.

questions.text: Tolazoline is used as___?

choices.text: A thrombin inhibitor used during peripheral angiography procedures
A vasodilator in treating coronary artery stenosis during angiography procedures
A vasoconstrictor in treatment of varices

questions.solution:
Tolazoline is used as a vasodilator in treating coronary artery stenosis during angiography procedures.

Tolazoline and phentolamine are alpha receptor blockers, therefore produce vasodilatation.

questions.text: Sweet syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Sweet syndrome is also known as acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis as it demonstrates intense dermal neutrophilic infiltrates with little evidence of primary vasculitis.

It presents with non-ulcerative lesions which have the following characteristics:

  • Tender
  • Plaques or nodules
  • Red/plum-colored (erythematous)
  • Heals with little scarring
  • On trunk, head, and limbs
  • Associated with:
    • High fever
    • Neutrophilic polymorphonuclear leukocytosis
    • Elevated ESR
  • Associated systemic diseases/Malignancy:
    • AML
    • Myeloma
    • Adenocarcinoma

Treatment of choice is corticosteroids.

questions.text: Which is the most common malignant tumour of the minor salivary glands?
questions.solution:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of minor salivary glands.

It is a malignant tumour with a deceptively benign histologic appearance characterized by indolent, locally invasive growth with high propensity for local recurrence and distant metastasis.

Surgical removal is often difficult due to invasion into adjacent structures and completely negative margins may not be attainable.

The most common site of distant metastasis is the lung, followed by bone, liver and brain.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: All of the following statements about surveillance are true except_____________

choices.text: It provides information about changing health trends
Surveillance is a part of monitoring
Health policies can be modified based on surveillance alone
It can provide public health disaster warnings

questions.solution:
Surveillance is not a part of monitoring. In contrast, monitoring is a part of surveillance.

Monitoring: Routine measurements are used for detecting changes in the environment or health status of a population. The analysis of these measurements is called monitoring.

Surveillance: There are factors which determine occurrence and distribution of diseases and other conditions of ill health. These factors are continuously scrutinised in surveillance. Monitoring is one of the essential components of surveillance concept. Objectives of surveillance are:

  • To provide information about changing health trends
  • To provide feedback which can change health policy
  • To provide public health disaster warnings

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes oligospermia?
questions.solution:
Sulfasalazine can cause a reversible infertility in males owing to changes in sperm number (oligospermia) and morphology.

Note: The data related to the possibilty of methotrexate causing oligospermia in humans is conflicting. Hence, sulfaslazine is considered to be a better option in this scenario.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the epidemiology and genetics of alcoholism are true except :

choices.text: Approximately 60% of the risk for alcohol abuse disorders is attributed to genetics.
At least 20% of all patients seen in primary care offices have an alcohol use disorder.
Children of alcoholics have a 10-fold higher risk of alcohol abuse and dependence even if adopted early in life and raised by non-alcoholics.
Presence of a mutation of aldehyde dehydrogenase that results in intense flushing with alcohol consumption confers a decreased risk of alcohol dependence.

questions.solution:
Children of alcoholics have a 4 fold (and not 10 fold) higher risk of alcohol abuse and dependence. This risk is conferred even if the children are adopted early and raised by non-alcoholics.

Other Options: 

  • Approximately 60% of the risk for alcohol abuse disorders is attributed to genetics. The genetic factors that appear to be most strongly linked to alcohol use disorder include genes that are linked to impulsivity, schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder.
  • It is estimated that 20% of all patients have at least mild alcohol use disorder.
  • A mutation in aldehyde dehydrogenase that is more common in individuals of Asian descent results in intense flushing when alcohol is consumed and confers a decreased risk of alcohol dependence. Conversely, genetic variants that lead to a low sensitivity to alcohol increases the risk of  subsequent alcohol use disorder as higher doses of alcohol are required to reach the same effects.
  • The chance of spontaneous remission of alcohol use disorder is 20%. If drinking continues with remission, the life span will decrease by about 10 years, with leading causes of death being heart disease, cancer, suicide, and accidents.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for urgent operative intervention for massive hemoptysis?

choices.text: Failure of CT scan to localize bleeding

questions.text: Ectopic rest of normal tissue is known as __________
questions.solution:
Choristoma is ectopic rest of normal tissue. It is a normally arranged tissue at a different anatomical site.

Abnormally arranged tissue at normal site is hamartoma.

questions.text: As per Nottingham histologic score of breast cancer , cribriform patterns of cells are seen in which of the following grade?
questions.solution:
As per Nottingham histologic score of breast cancer, cribriform patterns of cell are seen in Grade I.

Nottingham histologic score is a scoring system to assess the grade of breast cancers.

It is a total score based on 3 different sub-scores. The 3 sub-scores are assigned based on 3 components of how the breast cancer cells look under a microscope for tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism and mitotic rate and points are added to divide carcinomas into Grade I (well differentiated), Grade II (moderately differentiated), Grade III(poorly differentiated).

  • Grade I: Carcinomas in tubular pattern or cribriform pattern of cells with monomorphic nuclei.
  • Grade II: Carcinomas with less tubular formation and more solid nests of cells and pleomorphic nuclei.
  • Grade III: Carcinomas invade as ragged nests or solid sheets of cell with enlarged irregular nuclei,numerous mitotic figures and central areas of tumour necrosis.

questions.text: In judicial hanging, the knot is placed ________.

choices.text: At the angle of right jaw
At the back of the neck
As per the choice of the hangman

questions.solution:
In judicial hanging, the knot is placed at the angle of the right jaw.

Judicial hanging

  • Face of the person is covered with a dark mask, he is made to stand on a platform over trapdoors, which open downwards when a blot is drawn.
  • Rope is looped around the neck and the person is allowed to drop for 5-7 meters according to weight, age, and build of the person.
  • Sudden stop causes fracture dislocation usually at the C2-C3 or C3-C4 vertebra level and rupture of the brainstem between pons and medulla. (hangman fracture).
  • Death is instantaneous but heartbeat may continue for 15-20 minutes and spasmodic muscle jerking may occur for a considerable time.
  • Asphyxia signs are not seen in properly performed judicial hangings.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding cefepime?

choices.text: It is less stable against plasmid mediated beta-lactamase
It possesses anti-pseudomonal action comparable to that of ceftazidime
It has gram-negative activity similar to that of ceftriaxone
Its dose need not be reduced in renal pathology

questions.solution:
Cefepime possesses anti-pseudomonal action comparable to that of ceftazidime. 

  • Cefepime, a fourth-generation cephalosporin is more stable against plasmid-mediated beta-lactamase.
  • It is active against Staph. aureus, Enterobacter, and Citrobacter.
  • It possesses anti-pseudomonal activity comparable to that of ceftazidime and gram-positive activity similar to that of ceftriaxone.
  • All cephalosporins, except cefoperazone and ceftriaxone, are eliminated primarily by kidneys, thus dose adjustment is required in renal insufficiency.
  • Cefepime has a short t1/2 (2 hours) and needs to be given 8 hourly.

questions.text: Artery which doesn’t contribute to formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus is
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis formed in Little’s area. It is situated in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, just above the nasal vestibule. It is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults.

The arteries contributing to it are:

    • Sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
    • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
    • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery which supplies the nasal septum but doesn’t contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

questions.text: What is the Injury Severity Score for the trauma to be classified as a serious injury?
questions.solution:
ISS in the 16-25 range is defined as a serious injury.

The Injury severity score (ISS) ranges from 1 to 75, with severity groupings being defined as

  • Minor injury (less than 9),
  • Moderate injury (between 9 and 16),
  • Serious injury (between 16 and 25), and
  • Severe injury (more than 25)

The ISS is defined as the sum of squares of the highest Abbreviated Injury Scale grade in the 3 most severely injured body regions.

Six body regions are defined, as follows: the thorax, abdomen and visceral pelvis, head and neck, face, bony pelvis and extremities, and external structures. Only one injury per body region is allowed.

 

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: MHC class III genes encode_________
questions.solution:
MHC class III genes encode Tumor necrosis factor.

The major antigens determining histocompatibility in human beings are alloantigens, characteristically found on the surface leukocytes. Human MHC antigens are therefore synonymous with human leukocyte antigens, and the MHC complex of genes with the HLA complex.

The HLA complex of genes is located on the short arm of chromosome 6 and consists of three separate clusters of genes:

  • Class I :Comprising A, B and C loci.
  • Class II:Comprising D region (DR,DQ,DP)
  • Class III:Comprising C2 & C4, properdin factor B, heat shock protein, TNF- alpha and beta.

questions.text: A couple has come for pre-conceptional counseling to make a decision on pregnancy planning. The method of communication used for counseling to help the couple to make a decision about health is known as_________.
questions.solution:
The method of communication used for counselling, wherein a person is helped to make a health decision is known as the GATHER approach, e.g. contraceptive counselling. Expansion:

  • G- Greet
  • A- Ask
  • T- Tell options or give answers
  • H- Help in making choices
  • E- Explain everything about the decision
  • R- Return for follow-up

Other options:

Option A: Delphi method: It is a systematic interactive forecasting method which is used to obtain a consensus forecast, i.e. to determine the degree of agreement on a topic. This method uses questionnaires, which are answered by experts in two or more rounds.

Option C: Spikes protocol is used to convey distressing information and break bad news in an organised manner to patients and families.

Option D: Demonstration is a carefully prepared presentation on how to perform a certain task, skill, or procedure. It arouses interest and incites ‘learning by doing’ and 'seeing is believing’ philosophies.

Related Pearl: Methods of Health Communication

questions.text: The image given below depicts a skin manifestation of a neurocutaneous disorder. Which of the following conditions given below are not associated with this neurocutaneous disorder?
questions.solution:
The image shows the shagreen patch seen in tuberous sclerosis. Out of the given options, Lisch nodules is not associated with tuberous sclerosis. Lisch nodules are associated with neurofibromatosis.

Clinical features of tuberous sclerosis:

  • CNS involvement (hallmark of tuberous sclerosis)
    • Subependymal nodules are lesions found along the wall of the lateral ventricles where they undergo calcification
    • These benign subependymal nodules lesions can grow into subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGA)

questions.text: Differential coliform count is done by ___________
questions.solution:
Differential coliform count is done by Eijkman test.

It is done to confirm that coliform bacilli detected in the presumptive test are infact, E.coli.

Methodology: Following the presumptive test , subcultures are made from all the bottles showing acid and gas to fresh tubes of single strength Mac conkey medium pre warmed to 37 degree celcius .These tubes are incubated at 44 degree celcius and examined after 24 hours.

Interpretation:Tubes exhibiting gas in durham's tubes are deemed to contain E.Coli .From the number of positive tubes obtained ,the number of E.coli bacteria present in the water sample tested can be estimated by referring to Mc cardy's probability tables.The presence of e.coli can be further confirmed by testing for indole production and citrate utilisation.

Note:Durham tubes are used in microbiology to detect production of gas by microorganisms. They are simply smaller test tubes inserted upside down in another test tube. This small tube is initially filled with the solution in which the microorganism is to be grown.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about Refetoff’s syndrome?
questions.solution: Refetoff’s syndrome is caused due to end-organ resistance to T4, not a defect in thyroglobulin production. The thyroid hormone levels(T4 levels) are elevated but the thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level is normal.

questions.text: Genu valgum due to fluorosis is seen in population mainly consuming ____________
questions.solution:
A type of fluorosis causing genu valgum and osteoporosis is seen in population mainly consuming jowar (sorghum). This is because diets based on sorghum(jowar) promotes a higher retention of ingested fluoride than diets based on rice. It has been reported in some districts of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu.

Fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: 1.5mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis: >10mg/L

Nalgonda technique is used for defluoridation which involves addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation and filtration.

questions.text: In a sample of DNA if adenine is 23%, what will be the amount of guanine?
questions.solution:
In a sample of DNA, if adenine is 23%, guanine will be 27%.

This is based on Chargaff’s rule which states that the number of purines is equal to the number of pyrimidines.

Purines include adenine and guanine. Pyrimidines include thymine and cytosine. The two strands of DNA are complementary to each other. So, the adenine of one strand will pair with thymine of the opposite strand, while guanine will pair with cytosine.

  • Step 1:

No of adenine = No of thymine

So adenine + thymine = 46%

Guanine + cytosine = 54%

  • Step 2:

No of guanine = No of cytosine

So, amount of guanine = 54/2 = 27%

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)?

choices.text: Over 50% left main coronary artery stenosis
One vessel disease without proximal LAD artery involvement

questions.solution:
CABG or PCI is not recommended in one vessel disease without proximal LAD artery involvement.

CABG is also not considered appropriate in asymptomatic patients who are at a low risk of MI or death.

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: Revised Ghent criteria takes into account all of the following except___________

choices.text: Cardinal clinical signs in absence of family history
Presence or absence of fibrillin mutation

questions.solution:
Revised Ghent criteria does not take into account the presence of defective collagen synthesis.

Clinical diagnosis of Marfan syndrome is currently based on the revised Ghent criteria which takes into account:

  • Family history
  • Cardinal clinical signs in absence of family history
  • Presence or absence of fibrillin mutation

In general major involvement of two major organ systems (skeletal, cardiovascular, ocular and skin) and minor involvement of another organ is required for diagnosis.

Marfan’s syndrome: It is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder.

  • This autosomal dominant syndrome has pleiotropic manifestations involving primarily the ocular, cardiovascular, and skeletal systems.
  • Occurs due to a missense mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene located on chromosome 15 at band q21.1 (15q21.1).

Morphological features:

  1. Skeletal abnormalities:
    1. Typically the patient is unusually tall with exceptionally long extremities and long, tapering fingers and toes.
    2. Hyperextensibility due to laxity of joint ligaments.
    3. The head is commonly dolichocephalic (long-headed).
    4. A variety of spinal deformities may appear, including kyphosis, scoliosis, or rotation or slipping of the dorsal or lumbar vertebrae.
    5. The chest is classically deformed, presenting either pectus excavatum (deeply depressed sternum) or a pigeon-breast deformity.
  2. Ocular changes:
    1. Most characteristic is bilateral subluxation or dislocation (usually outward and upward) of the lens, referred to as ectopia lentis.
  3. Cardiovascular lesions:
    1. Most life-threatening features of this disorder. The two most common lesions are mitral valve prolapse and, of greater importance, dilation of the ascending aorta due to cystic medial necrosis.

questions.text: Enucleation is indicated in the treatment of retinoblastoma when the tumour involves____________
questions.solution:
All of the above options are correct.

Indication of enucleation in retinoblastoma:

  • Tumor involves more than half of retina.
  • Optic nerve involved.
  • Glaucoma is present & anterior chamber is involved.

 

Note: Optic nerve involvement is treated by Enucleation + Post op Radiotherapy + Post op Chemotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for resection in an asymptomatic hemangioma?
questions.solution:
Diagnostic certainty is not a criterion for resection in an asymptomatic hemangioma. However, in rare cases of diagnostic uncertainty, resection may be necessary for a definitive diagnosis to be made.

Other indications for resection are –

  • Rupture
  • Significant change in size
  • Kasabach Merritt syndrome

questions.text: An IT employee is feeling guilty, hopeless, and not able to concentrate on work. His symptoms started 3 years back when he entered college. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of guilt, hopelessness, and difficulty in concentrating over a period of more than 2 years, is suggestive of dysthymia (persistent depressive disorder).

The DSM 5 and ICD-11 criteria for diagnosis of dysthymia: 

A. Depressed mood for most of the day as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years. In children and adolescents at least 1 year.

B. Presence of two (or more) of the following while being depressed.

  1. Poor appetite or overeating
  2. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  3. Low energy or fatigue
  4. Low self-esteem
  5. Poor concentration and/or difficulty making decisions
  6. Feelings of hopelessness

C. During the 2-year period (1 year for children or adolescents) of the disturbance, the individ­ual has never been without the symptoms in criteria A and B for more than 2 months at a time.

D. Criteria for a major depressive disorder may be continuously present for 2 years.

E. There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode, and criteria have never been met for cyclothymic disorder.

F. The disturbance is not better explained by a persistent schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

G. The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition (e.g. hypothyroidism).

H. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Option C: Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and usually do not last more than 6 months after the stressor ends.

Option D: Cyclothymic disorder is symptomatically a mild form of bipolar II disorder, characterized by episodes of hypomania and mild depression.

questions.text: Case fatality rate is typically used in all of the following conditions except__________
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate is typically used in acute infectious diseases such as food poisoning, measles and cholera. Case fatality rate may not be useful in case of HIV infection because the period from onset to death is long and variable in chronic diseases such as HIV.

Usefulness of case fatality rate is limited in chronic diseases.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: The most common cause of male infertility and female infertility is ________ and ___________ respectively

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in severe head injuries?
questions.solution:
Cushing’s ulcer is seen in traumatic head injury, brain tumours and intracranial infections. Increased ICP leads to overstimulation of the Vagus nerve and increased secretion of gastric acid which causes gastro-duodenal ulcer formation.

Other options:

  • When stress ulceration is associated with major burns, these lesions are referred to as Curling ulcers.
  • Martorell’s ulcers are seen in patients with prolonged/suboptimal controlled hypertension.
  • Marjolin's ulcers reflect malignant degeneration arising within a pre-existing cicatrix or scar.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about burns?

choices.text: Palmar surface technique is not used for the assessment of medium burns
Lund and Browder chart is an inaccurate chart for burn assessment in children
Erythema has to be included when making initial assessment of burns
The greatest amount of fluid loss in burn patients is after the first 24 hours

questions.solution:
Palmar surface technique is not used for the assessment of medium burns. The surface area of a patient's palm (including fingers) is roughly 0.8% of total body surface area. Palmar surface are can be used to estimate relatively small burns (< 15%) or very large burns(> 85). For medium sized burns, it is inaccurate.

When calculating burn area, erythema should not be included. This may take a few hours to fade, so some overestimation is inevitable if the burn is estimated acutely.​

Lund and Browder chart if used correctly, is the most accurate method to asses burn areas. It compensates for the variation in body shape with age and therefore can give an accurate assessment of burns area in children.

The greatest amount of fluid loss in burn patients is in the first 24 hours after injury. For the first eight to 12 hours, there is a general shift of fluid from the intravascular to interstitial fluid compartments.

questions.text: In vitamin C deficiency, post translational modification of which of the following amino acid is defective ?
questions.solution:
In vitamin C deficiency, post translational modification of lysine is defective.It is required for the post translation modification ,hydroxylation of lysine and proline.

Clinical significance:Vitamin C  along with proline and lysine is required for formation of healthy collagen.

 One of the main functions of ascorbate is protein hydroxylation . Protein hydroxylation is a post-translational modification in which a hydroxyl group is added to a protein residue. Protein hydroxylation is involved in the maturation of collagen. Without ascorbate, collagen is not hydroxylated and the collagen molecule is structurally unstable . Ascorbate is also directly involved in the biosynthetic pathway of carnitine . Impaired synthesis of carnitine, along with collagen, results in the common symptoms of scurvy.

 

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a lymph node is as seen below. Which of the following condition does this pathology represent?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows a granuloma formed by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleate giant cells and surrounded by lymphocytes. This is an example for Type IV or cell mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

Type IV or cell mediated hypersensitivity reaction:

  • Seen with persistent or nondegradable antigens, such as tubercle bacilli in lungs or other tissues. Infiltrate is dominated by macrophages over a period of 2 or 3 weeks.
  • With sustained activation, macrophages often undergo a morphologic transformation into epithelioid cells (large epithelium-like cells with abundant cytoplasm).
  • A microscopic aggregation of epithelioid cells, usually surrounded by a collar of lymphocytes, is referred to as a granuloma.
  • This pattern of inflammation, called granulomatous inflammation is typically associated with strong TH1-cell activation and high-level production of cytokines such as IFN-γ.

questions.text: Which of the following patients has the highest risk of progression to chronic kidney disease (CKD)?

choices.text: A 30 year old man with an eGFR of 50mL/min/1.73m2 and 350mg/g of persistent albuminuria
A 45 year old man with an eGFR of 90mL/min/1.73m2 and < 30mg/g of persistent albuminuria
A 55 year old man with an eGFR of 70mL/min/1.73m2 and 100mg/g of persistent albuminuria
A 65 year old woman with an eGFR of 35mL/min/1.73m2 and < 30mg/g of persistent albuminuria

questions.solution:
A 30 year old man with an eGFR of 50mL/min/1.73m2 and 350mg/g of persistent albuminuria has the greatest risk of developing CKD.

Chronic Kidney Disease:

  • It encompasses a spectrum of different pathophysiologic process associated with abnormal kidney function and a progressive decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
  • Stages of CKD are stratified by both estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) and the degree of albuminuria in order to predict the risk of progression of CKD.
  • Although age impacts GFR, it is not an independent criterion for risk of progression to CKD.

Stages of CKD based on GFR:

  • Stage 1:   GFR >/= 90 mL/min/1.73m2
  • Stage 2:   GFR = 60-89 mL/min/1.73m2
  • Stage 3a: GFR = 45-59 mL/min/1.73m2
  • Stage 3b: GFR = 30-44mL/min/1.73m2
  • Stage 4:   GFR = 15-29 mL/min/1.73m2
  • Stage 5:   GFR < 15mL/min/1.73m2

questions.text: Hemoglobin levels were measured in 200 pregnant women. The results showed a mean hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL with a standard deviation of 0.5 g/dL. Assuming that the distribution is normal, how many women will have hemoglobin levels <9.5 g/dL?
questions.solution:
In the given population, 5 women will have hemoglobin (Hb) levels < 9.5 g/dL.

In a normal distribution, the distribution of values around the mean is as follows:

  • 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 SD of the mean. 
  • 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 SD of the mean. 
  • 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 SD of the mean.

In a normal distribution, 2 SD from the mean will have 95% of the participants. Therefore, 95% of pregnant women will have Hb levels of 10.5±2*0.5 = 10.5±1 =  9.5-11.5 g/dL.

The remaining 2.5% of women will have Hb >11.5 g/dL and 2.5% of women will have Hb level <9.5 g/dL.

2.5% of 200 = 5. Hence, 5 women will have Hb of <9.5 g/dL.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text:
True statement regarding Neutrophil extracellular traps:
a)	They are extracellular fibrillar networks that provide high concentration of antimicrobial substance at sites of infections except during sepsis.
b)	Produced by neutrophils in response to infectious pathogens except fungi and inflammatory mediators except interferons.
c)	In the process of NET formation ,nuclei of neutrophils are lost ,leading to death of cells.
d)	The nuclear chromatin in NETs has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune disease.
questions.solution:
Out of the given statements, statement C and D are correct.

Neutrophil extracellular traps: They are extracellular fibrillar networks that provide high concentration of antimicrobial substance at sites of infection and prevent microbes by trapping them in fibrils.

  • Produced by neutrophils in response to infectious pathogens (mainly bacteria and fungi) and inflammatory mediators such as chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins and ROS.
  • In the process of NET formation, nuclei of neutrophils are lost, leading to death of cells.
  • NETs have also been detected in the blood during sepsis and is believed that their formation in circulation is dependent on platelet activation.
  • The nuclear chromatin in NETs(which includes histones and associated DNA) has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly lupus.

questions.text: A mother brings her infant to you with the given finding. Which of the following is not a feature of this hypervitaminosis?

choices.text: Pigmentation of the face, palms, and soles

questions.solution:
This image shows carotenoderma (of the nose), associated with hypervitaminosis A. Mucous membranes are uninvolved in this condition.

Carotenoderma is a condition associated with hypervitaminosis A. It is characterized by prominent yellow‐orange pigmentation of the face, palms, and soles of the feet. It can mimic jaundice and medication‐induced pigmentation, but unlike jaundice, carotenoderma spares the mucous membranes.

questions.text: If the power of a lens is 1.5 D, what will be its focal length?
questions.solution:
Focal length of the lens will be 0.66 m.

Refractive power (dioptre) = 1/ Focal length in meters

So in this question: 

Refractive power (D) = 1.5 = 1/ Focal length in meters

Hence, Focal length in metres =1/ 1.5 = 2/3 = 0.66

questions.text: Which is the most common benign tumour of the sinonasal tract?
questions.solution:
Osteoma is a benign, slow-growing osteoblastic lesion and is the most common benign tumor of the sinonasal tract.

They are generally diagnosed between the 2nd and 5th decades of life, with a slight male preponderance.  The frontal sinus is the most frequently involved anatomic site followed by the ethmoid, the maxillary sinus, and, more rarely, the sphenoid sinus.    

Osteomas can be observed in conjunction with Gardner syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by multiple polyps of the colon in association with osteomas of the skull and multiple soft tissue tumors.

questions.text: A 48-year old man presented with the following skin lesion. It was noted that the lesions got aggravated after he was started on a beta-blocker. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of psoriasis with the image showing a psoriatic plaque, with a silvery center surrounded by a reddish border.

Plaque/ discoid psoriasis, also known as psoriasis vulgaris accounts for almost 90% of all psoriasis cases. It presents as a papulosquamous rash, with reddish edematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales, which are well-demarcated from unaffected skin with sharply delineated edges. Plaques may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone called the halo or ring of Woronoff. The scalp is one of the most common and first affected areas in plaque psoriasis, while other affected areas include elbows, knees, and back.

It can also be classified based on the site involved:

Plaque psoriasis (most common): sharply demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales, commonly present on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, etc.).


Guttate psoriasis: small scattered erythematous papules with silvery scales; often triggered by infections.


Erythrodermic psoriasis: confluent plaques affecting nearly all of the skin but often sparing the central face, with electrolyte and thermoregulation abnormalities.

Pustular psoriasis: presence of superficial pustules; generalized, annular, palmar-plantar, localized, and exanthemic variants are described.

Scalp psoriasis: well-demarcated plaques on the retro auricular areas and posterior upper neck.

Flexural/ inverse psoriasis: plaques affecting intertriginous folds, scaling may be less prominent.

Napkin psoriasis: may be seen in napkin (diaper) area in newborns.

Nail psoriasis: pits, splinter hemorrhages, oil drop sign (translucent yellow discoloration of the nail caused by parakeratosis of the nail bed), salmon patches, and leukonychia are common on the nail plate.

questions.text: Vaccine for carcinoma cervix which can only be given to females is__________
questions.solution:
All the above vaccines can be given to both boys and girls.

Cervarix Gardasil (silgard) Gardasil 9
Bivalent vaccine against HPV 16,18 Quadrivalent vaccine against HPV 6, 11 ,16, 18 Nonavalent against 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58
Can be given to boys Can be given to boys Can be given to boys
0.5 mL at 0, 1, 6 months 0.5 mL at 0, 2, 6 months 0.5 mL at 0, 2, 6 months 
Important side effect: Syncopal effect  -  -

 

Please note : Cervarix can be used in males and females from the age of 9 years.

HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18 are prevalent in both cervical and non-cervical diseases, and the vaccines can prevent a range of HPV associated diseases. HPV types 16 and 18 contribute to 30% of vaginal, vulval, and oropharyngeal cancers, 20% of oral cancers, and 80% of anal cancers.HPV 16 is the most commonly detected type in male (HPV associated) cancer.

Recent update: Gardasil 9 has received expanded indication which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and head and neck cancers caused by HPV types 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

questions.text: Exclusive breast feeding is protective against plasmodium because of____________

choices.text: Low levels of Para amino benzoic acid

questions.solution:
Plasmodium requires para amino benzoic acid (PABA) for its replication. Since breast milk has low levels of Para amino benzoic acid, exclusive breastfeeding is protective against plasmodium. There is no eveidence of this effect being specific for any particular species of plasmodium.

Components in breast milk which protect against malaria:

  • Lactoferrin: Iron is required for the multiplication of plasmodium falciparum. Since lactoferrin binds to iron, it inhibits multiplication of plasmodium falciparum.
  • Secretory IgA
  • Low levels of PABA

 Components of breast milk and diseases they protect against:

  • E.histolytica
Lactoferrin
  • E. coli, Salmonella, Shigella 
  • E.histolytica, G.lamblia
  • Plasmodium falciparum
  • Rotavirus
Bifidus factor E.coli, Salmonella, Shigella
Low levels of para amino benzoic acid Plasmodium

questions.text: True about Zasko's phenomenon is___________

choices.text: It is elicited by striking the lower  3rd  of the quadriceps femoris muscle 1 cm above patella with a reflex hammer
Reaction seen is upward movement of patella because of contraction of the whole quadricep muscle

questions.solution:

It is seen upto 1 to 2 hrs of death. It is elicited by striking lower third of quadriceps femoris muscle 10cm above the patella with a reflex hammer.

questions.text: The condition of prosopagnosia usually results from dysfunction or damage to which area of the cerebral cortex?

choices.text: Junction of the parietal and temporal lobe on the nondominant side of the brain
Underside of the medial occipital and temporal lobes

questions.solution:
Prosopagnosia usually occurs in people who have extensive damage on the medial undersides of both occipital lobes and along the medioventral surfaces of the temporal lobes.

Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize faces.

questions.text: A 25 year old female presents with a neck swelling. Isotope scan of her thyroid gland shows a “cold” nodule. This nodule is removed and microscopy is as seen below. All are true about the tumour except:

choices.text: Follicular variant is the most common variant
Diagnosis can be made based on nuclear features, even in the absence of typical architecture
Associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation

questions.solution:
The image shows papillary carcinoma of thyroid with papillae lined by cells with overlapping and clearing of nuclei and inclusions. Involvement of blood vessels by tumor cells is relatively uncommon but metastases to adjacent cervical lymph nodes occur in up to half of the cases.

  • Presents as painless nodule or mass in the neck or cervical node in women of reproductive age.
  • Usually cold nodule on a scan
  • Branching papillae and follicles with fibrovascular stalk
  • Nuclear changes  - Optically clear -  Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, nuclear grooves
  • Risk factors – Exposure to ionizing radiation, Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Diagnosis can be made based on these nuclear features, even in the absence of papillary architecture
  • Psammoma bodies are often present
  • Most common variant of papillary carcinoma is the follicular variant
  • Tall cell variant – increased frequencies of vascular invasion, extrathyroidal extension, and cervical and distant metastases.
  • Excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with perifollicular hemorrhages is diagnosed with scurvy. X-ray of the child is done. Which of the following radiological features is incorrectly matched?

choices.text: White line of Frankel- dense zone of provisional calcification
Wimberger's ring sign- ring shaped epiphysis
Pelkan spur- small portion of detached bone

questions.solution:
Trummerfeld zone is a radiolucent zone beneath the Frankel's line due to lack of mineralized osteoid. 

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: Which of the following statements given below is false about the instrument shown in the image?

choices.text: It is used for skeletal traction of upper end of tibia
It is used along with the Bohler's stirrup
It is used for skeletal traction of Calcaneum

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a Steinmann pin.

This is a stout straight steel rod of diameter ranging from 3 to 6 mm.

It is used for skeletal traction in common sites such as the upper end of the tibia, supracondylar region of the femur and Calcaneum.

Along with Bohler’s stirrup, it is used to hold the pin during skeletal traction.

questions.text: Naegele’s pelvis is _________

choices.text: Absence of both sides of ala of sacrum
Due to arrested development of one side of the ala of sacrum

questions.solution:
• Naegele’s pelvis is due to the arrested development of one side of the ala of sacrum.
  • Robert’s pelvis (transversely contracted pelvis): This is an extremely rare abnormality. Ala of both sides are absent and the sacrum is fused with the innominate bones. Delivery is done by cesarean section.
  • Kyphotic pelvis: This pelvic deformity is secondary to the kyphotic changes of the vertebral column either following tuberculosis or rickets.

questions.text: In a splenectomised patient there is increase risk of infection by all organisms except___________
questions.solution:
In a splenectomised patient there is increase risk of infection by all above organisms except staphylococcus aureus.

Among the following all are capsulated except staphylococcus aureus.

Certain complements can attach to these organisms and once delivered to spleen , their uptake is facilitated by complement receptors present on splenic phagocyte surface. Spleen has an important role in removing these capsulated organisms where opanisation takes place.

questions.text: Failure rate of Pomeroy method of tubal ligation is ___________
questions.solution:
Failure rate of Pomeroy method of tubal ligation is 0.4.

Procedure of Pomeroy method :

  • The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut (any rapidly absorbing suture) and excised.
  • There should be an adequate margin between the suture and the cut end to prevent the cut ends of the tube from slipping out of the suture.
  • The cut ends of the tube are inspected to visualize the tubal lumen; this confirms resection of a full thickness of the tube.
  • As the tubal stumps heal, the suture absorbs and the ends fall apart.

Condom 10-14
Combined Pill 0.1
Vasectomy 0.15
Tubal ligation 0.4

questions.text: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is seen in____________
questions.solution:
Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is seen in pelvic inflammatory disease.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is a perihepatitis which occurs in the setting of pelvic inflammatory disease ( PID ).

It occurs in approximately 10 percent of women with acute PID.

Gonococcal salpingits / chlamydial infection → transperitoneal / vascular spread → inflammation of the liver capsule and peritoneal surfaces of the anterior right upper quadrant.

Characterized by right upper quadrant abdominal pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred to the right shoulder.

The image below represents the Violin-string adhesions of chronic Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is treated by amphotericin B. Posaconazole can also be used. However, other azoles are not effective against this fungus.

Voriconazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. It can also be used for Candida species (including glabrata and krusei), Scedosporium and Fusarium.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be stopped abruptly without any withdrawal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Fluoxetine can be stopped abruptly without any withdrawal symptoms.

Fluoxetine is the longest-acting SSRI. Fluoxetine has plasma t1/2 of 48-72 hours. It is metabolized to an active product, norfluoxetine, which may have plasma concentrations greater than those of fluoxetine. The elimination half-life of norfluoxetine is about three times longer than fluoxetine (180 hours) and contributes to the longest half-life of all the SSRIs. Therefore, the level of the drug in the body falls slowly at a rate to which the brain can adapt when the dosage is reduced.

Paroxetine and sertraline are short-acting SSRIs and are associated with a discontinuation syndrome characterized by dizziness, and paresthesias beginning 1 or 2 days after stopping the drug and persisting for 1 week or longer.

Venlafaxine is a SNRI. All the SNRIs have been associated with a discontinuation syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana?

choices.text: Unemployment allowance is not given in case of closure of factory
Unemployment allowance is given in case of employment injury
Allowance is given at 50% of the daily wage for a maximum of 2 years
To qualify for the scheme, worker must have worked for more than 2 years

questions.solution:
Unemployment allowance under Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana (RGSKY) is given at the rate of 50% of daily wage for a maximum of 2 years.

RGSKY is a scheme of ESI that provides unemployment allowance to an insured person going out of employment involuntarily, on account of:

  • closure of a factory or establishment 
  • retrenchment (laying off employees due to economic difficulty)
  • permanent disability due to nonemployment injury

Allowance and eligibility criteria of Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana (updated in 2019):

  • The allowance is given at the rate of 50% of the daily wage for a maximum of 2 years.
  • To qualify for the scheme the worker must have worked in that setup for >3 years.

Note: Disability due to employment injury is covered under disablement benefits of ESI Act, 1948.

  • Temporary disability: 90% of wages until disablement lasts.
  • Permanent disability: 90% of wages as a life pension on the basis of loss of earning capacity.
  • Dependants benefit: 90% of wage as monthly payment to the dependants of the deceased person, in cases where death occurs due to employment injury or occupational hazards.

questions.text:
The flow-volume curve after the spirometry of a patient is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:

The dotted curve indicates the normal pattern.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an obstructive pattern on the flow-volume curve. So the most likely diagnosis of this patient is bronchial asthma.

The flow-volume curve above shows a concave upward pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called a scooped-out or coved pattern and is observed in conditions responsible for airflow obstruction like asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, etc. 

Other options: 

Option A: Myasthenia gravis shows a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by decreased total lung capacity and vital capacity. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right.

Option B: Tracheal stenosis shows a fixed upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve. In this condition, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration. This leads to the flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop. 

Option C: Vocal cord paralysis shows a variable upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. 

The image below shows various patterns of flow-volume curves.

questions.text: Pink tetralogy of fallot is present when there is__________
questions.solution:
In pink or acyanotic tetralogy of fallot, the patient is not visibly cyanotic. It is present when there is mild to moderate right ventricular outflow obstruction and a balanced shunt is present through VSD.

Tetralogy of Fallot: It is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease. Four anatomical components of TOF include

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow - Pulmonic stenosis (PS)
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
  • Overriding (or dextroposition) of the aorta

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl was brought to the emergency room with fever for 2 days, dyspnoea, drooling and inspiratory stridor. Lateral x-ray of her neck is given below. Which is the most common organism responsible for this condition in children worldwide?
questions.solution:
This is a case of acute epiglottitis since the child is having fever, dyspnoea, drooling and inspiratory stridor and the lateral x-ray neck shows thumb sign. The most common organism, overall in the world, in the case of acute epiglottitis, is streptococcus pneumoniae.

Note: Hemophilus influenzae type B is no longer the most common cause, overall in the world, after the widespread use of Hemophilus influenzae vaccination. Streptococci including Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci and Streptococcus pneumoniae has become more prevalent in the paediatric age group. 

Note:

The most common cause of epiglottitis:
In India - Hemophilus influenza.
Rest of the World - Strep. pneumonia.

Though Nelson mentions that H.influenza is not the most common cause of this condition, the latest edition of O.P Ghai still mentions H.influenza as the most common cause of acute epiglottitis. 
What it means is that, in India, even though cases of H. influenza are coming down due to increased vaccine coverage, still H. influenza remains the leading cause of acute epiglottitis in India.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign

Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: For a patient with a suspected inherited connective tissue disorder, identify the sign demonstrated below.
questions.solution:
The picture depicts Gorlin’s sign, which is the ability of patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) to touch the tip of the nose with the tip of their tongue.

EDS is a connective tissue disorder occurring due to genetic defects involved in collagen synthesis and action. It is characterized by hyperextensibility of skin, hypermobile joints, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

Other options:

Option A: Hertoghe’s sign is defined as the loss of lateral one-third of the eye-brows (superciliary madarosis) seen in leprosy, myxedema, atopic dermatitis, trichotillomania, ectodermal dysplasia, discoid lupus erythematosus, alopecia areata, syphilis, systemic sclerosis, HIV infection, and hypothyroidism.

Option B: Higoumenaki's sign refers to enlargement of the sternal end of the clavicle, frequently observed in patients with late congenital syphilis.

Option D: Gottron's sign refers to erythematous macules and patches overlying the elbows and/or knees seen in dermatomyositis.

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with widely metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer is admitted to the intensive care unit with a systolic blood pressure of 73/52 mmHg. She presented complaining of fatigue and worsening dyspnoea over the last 3-5 days. Her physical examination shows elevated neck veins. Chest radiograph shows a massive, water bottle-shaped heart shadow and no new pulmonary infiltrates. Which of the following additional findings is most likely present on physical examination?

choices.text: Fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration
Lack of fall of the jugular venous pressure with inspiration
Rapid y-descent of jugular venous pressure tracing

questions.solution:
Fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration is most likely to be present on physical examination.

The patient is likely to have pericardial tamponade from metastatic tumour cancer as suggested by her elevated neck veins, heart shadow shape and size, and predisposing condition. Because of the exaggerated interventricular dependence, the normal (<10 mmHg) fall is systemic blood pressure with inspiration is exaggerated (often >15mmHg) with cardiac tamponade. This is referred to as pulsus paradoxus, although it is in fact an augmentation of a normal finding.

Other options:

  • Kussmaul sign, or a lack of fall of the jugular venous pressure with inspiration, is a sign usually denoting a lack of compliance in the right ventricle, as seen most frequently in constrictive pericarditis, although it may be found in restrictive cardiomyopathy or massive pulmonary embolism.
  • A slow y-descent , which follows the peak of the v wave, of jugular venous pressure tracing is indicative of cardiac tamponade as the restricted ventricle is slow to fill during diastole. The x-descent (systolic) may be augmented because ventricular ejection results in relative unloading of the intrapericardial pressure.
  • Pulsus parvus et tardus, or small and slow arterial pulsation, is a late finding in aortic stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly matched regarding drug elimination?
questions.solution:
CYP3A4 (and not glucuronide conjugation) is involved in metabolism of simvastatin.

Metabolites of simvastatin, however, can be glucuronide conjugated. But in this case, the drug no longer remains as simvastatin.

Clinical relevance:

If another drug or substance induces UGT glucuronyl transferase, it will not affect the activity of simvastatin.

Other options:

CYP3A4 is also involved in metabolism of calcium channel blockers.

CYP2D6 is involved in metabolism of beta-blockers.

P-glycoprotein polymorphism decreases AUC of digoxin.

questions.text: Vitamin K is involved in synthesis of which of the following clotting factors?
questions.solution:
Vitamin K is involved in synthesis of Factor 10.

The vitamin K-dependent proteins can be divided into two classes:

  • Procoagulants - Factors II, VII, IX, and X
  • Anticoagulants - Proteins C, S and Z

The vitamin k-dependent proteins are a part of a family of serine proteinase (except for proteins S and Z) related to the trypsin/chymotrypsin super family.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a minor criterion for diagnosing fat embolism?
questions.solution:
Fat globules in sputum is a minor criterion for diagnosing fat embolism.

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.
