questions.text: A 35-year-old man died in a road traffic accident. On autopsy, the following appearance of the kidney was noted. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen

questions.solution:
The gross image suggests that the patient had autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). This condition is not associated with hepatic fibrosis. However, patients with autosomal recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD is associated with mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2. The multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure. Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include: 
  • Hepatic cysts - most common 
  • Seminal vesicle cysts - can result in infertility
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma
  • Pancreatic cysts 
  • Splenic cysts
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse 
There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients. 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Transport of ADP in and ATP out of mitochondria is inhibited by___________
questions.solution:
Transport of ADP into and ATP out of mitochondrion is inhibited by atractyloside. Hence it inhibits oxidative phosphorylation.

Other options:

  • Antibiotic oligomycin completely blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by blocking flow of protons through ATP synthtase.
  • Barburites like rotenone inhibit electron transport via complex I.
  • Cyanide inhibit complex IV and therefore totally arrest respiration.

questions.text: Which of the statements about kidney transplant is true?

choices.text: Right iliac fossa is a preferred site of implantation
Nonmelanocytic skin cancer is an absolute contraindication
The most common cause of graft loss is allograft nephropathy
HIV infection is an absolute contraindication

questions.solution:
The right iliac fossa is the preferred site because of its easy access to the recipient’s iliac vessels.

However, if a pancreas transplant is anticipated in the future or if now failed kidney grafts have been placed at the right iliac fossa, then the left iliac fossa is used for implantation.

Untreated and/or active malignancies are absolute contraindications to a transplant (with two exceptions: nonmelanocytic skin cancer and incidental renal cell cancer identified at the time of concurrent nephrectomy.

Currently, the most common cause of graft loss is recipient death (usually from cardiovascular causes) with a functioning graft. The second most common cause is chronic allograft nephropathy; characterized by a slow, unrelenting deterioration of graft function, it likely has multiple causes.

HIV infection was once a contraindication to transplantation; however, select patients with appropriate cell counts (CD4+ above 400 cells/mm3) and an undetectable viral load have good results with transplantation as a treatment modality for HIV-associated nephropathy.

questions.text: According to suggested norms, how many doctors should be present for a population of 10,000?

According to suggested norms for health manpower, a doctor should be present for every 1000 people. Hence a population of 10,000 should have 10 doctors.

questions.text: Identify the structures labeled in the image from 1 to 4.

choices.text: Decidua basalis, Decidua capsularis, Decidua parietalis, Amniotic cavity
Decidua parietalis, Decidua capsularis, Decidua basalis, Amniotic cavity
Decidua basalis, Decidua capsularis, Decidua parietalis, Uterine cavity
Decidua parietalis, Decidua capsularis, Decidua basalis, Uterine cavity

questions.solution:
The structures labeled in the above image are (1) Decidua parietalis, (2) Decidua capsularis, (3) Decidua basalis, and (4) Uterine cavity.

The decidua is the modified endometrium formed under the influence of progesterone and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) secreted by the cells of syncytiotrophoblast. After the implantation of the blastocyst, the decidua gets divided into 3 parts as follows:

  • Decidua capsularis: part surrounding the embryo and separating it from the uterine cavity
  • Decidua basalis: part deeper to the developing blastocyst that contributes to the maternal component of the placenta
  • Decidua parietalis: part lining the rest of the uterine cavity

The image given below shows the parts of decidua.

questions.text: Fundal images of two different forms of a condition are depicted in images A and B. Identify the true statement.

choices.text: A is treated with laser photocoagulation
B is the most common form of the condition
B is treated with intravitreal injection of anti VEGF

questions.solution:
The images A and B show Age-related macular degeneration.

  • Image A (shows drusens) - dry/ non exudative AMD
  • Image B – Wet/ exudative AMD

Wet/exudative AMD is treated with intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF.

AMD:

Dry (non-exudative, non-neovascular) AMD:

  • The most common form, comprising around 90% of the diagnosed disease. Geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry AMD.
  • No effective treatment is available. Antioxidants like lutein and zeoxanthine are given as prophylaxis.

Wet (exudative, neovascular) AMD:

  • It is much less common than dry, but is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss.
  • It is characterized by retinal pigment epithelial detachment and choroidal/sub retinal neovascularisation.
  • Treatment depends on the location of choroidal neovascularization membrane.
    • For extrafoveal membrane – laser photocoagulation
    • For subfoveal and juxta foveal treatment options are as follows:
      1. Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF
      2. Photodynamic therapy – dye used is verteporfin followed by exposure to light from diode
      3. Transpupillary thermotherapy

questions.text: Which of the following typically appears as a cavitating tumor?
questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma typically appears as a cavitating tumor.

Small cell lung cancers were known as oat cell cancers because of the packed nature of small dense cells.

Adenocarcinoma is now the most common of the Non-small cell lung cancer types, having overtaken squamous cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following manoeuvre’s used in breech delivery is correctly matched with the part of the baby delivered?

choices.text: Burns marshall -  chin to pubis delivery

questions.solution:
Lovset’s manoeuvre is correctly matched with delivery of extended arms in breech presentation.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Which of the following is a bone resorption marker?
questions.solution:
Cathepsin K is a cysteine proteinase expressed predominantly in osteoclasts, which has a high specificity for kinins, and is a marker for bone resorption.

It is essential for normal bone resorption and humans lacking cathepsin K exhibit pycnodysostosis, which is characterized by short stature and osteosclerosis.

The rest of the options are of bone formation markers.

questions.solution: It is a case of Clostridium difficile induced diarrhoea. Clostridium difficile should always be considered as a possible cause of diarrhoea in cancer patients who have received antibiotics.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of frequent episodes of gingival bleeding along with numerous petechiae on the leg. The platelet count is 50,000/microliter and the peripheral smear shows large platelets with normal morphology. Other laboratory investigations are normal. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is an autoimmune mediated condition
Antibodies are directed against platelet factor 4
There are increased number of megakaryocytes in bone marrow
The treatment is by administering I.V. immunoglobin

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). The false statement is that the antibodies are directed against platelet factor 4. Antibodies against platelet factor 4 are seen in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

ITP is an autoimmune disorder caused by antiplatelet antibodies that destroy platelets. The antibodies are directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. It can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary, associated with SLE, Hepatitis C, and HIV.

Acute ITP is usually seen in children, while chronic ITP occurs commonly in adults. Clinically, the patient may present with a history of easy bruising, gingival bleeding, petechiae, and ecchymoses. 

Investigations show isolated thrombocytopenia. Peripheral smear may show large platelets with normal morphology and bone marrow shows an increase in megakaryocytes (non-specific findings of thrombopoiesis). 

Initial treatment includes administering steroids and IVIg (intravenous immunoglobulin). TPO (thrombopoietin) receptor agonists, romiplostim and eltrombopag, are effective in increasing platelet counts in patients not responding to traditional treatment. Spleen is a major site for the removal of opsonized (targeted) platelets, and so, splenectomy remains a treatment option in severe thrombocytopenia and refractory cases.

Note- Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is an autoimmune condition, seen after the administration of heparin. It is more common with unfractionated heparin compared to low molecular weight heparins. This condition is not associated with bleeding. On the contrary, it is associated with thrombosis.

Related Pearl: Idiopathic/Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

It is characterized by

  • Isolated thrombocytopenia—the presence of antibody against platelet membrane glycoprotein and subsequent destruction in reticuloendothelial system
  • Normal bone marrow—normal or even increased number of megakaryocytes
  • Absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia. 

Types:

Acute (<6 months) and chronic (>6 months) idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

Features

Acute ITP

Chronic ITP

Peak incidence

2–6 years

20–40 years

Sex predilection

None

female: male ratio of 3:1 

Antecedent infection

Common 1 to 3 weeks before

Unusual

Onset of bleeding

Abrupt

Insidious

Platelet count

<20000/microlitre

30–80000/microlitre

Eosinophilia/lymphocytosis

Common

Rare

Duration

2–6 weeks

Months or years

Spontaneous remission

80% of cases

Uncommon

Related Pearl: Causes of Thrombocytopenia

I. Decreased Production of Platelets

  1. Selective impairment of platelet production
    • Drug-induced: alcohol, thiazides, cytotoxic drugs
    • Infections: measles, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  2. Nutritional deficiencies - B12, folate deficiency
  3. Bone marrow failure - aplastic anemia
  4. Bone marrow replacement - leukemia, disseminated cancer, granulomatous disease
  5. Ineffective hematopoiesis - myelodysplastic syndromes 

II. Decreased Platelet Survival

  1. Immunologic destruction
    • Primary autoimmune - chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura, acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura
    • Secondary autoimmune - systemic lupus erythematosus, B-cell lymphoid neoplasms
    • Alloimmune - posttransfusion and neonatal
    • Drug-associated - quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds
    • Infections - HIV, infectious mononucleosis (transient, mild), dengue fever
  2. Nonimmunologic destruction
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
    • Thrombotic microangiopathies
    • Giant hemangiomas

III. Sequestration - The spleen normally sequesters 30% to 35% of platelets. This can rise to 80% to 90% when the spleen is enlarged, producing moderate degrees of thrombocytopenia.

IV. Dilution - Transfusions

questions.text: During ward rounds, a third year resident is asked about markers of acute kidney injury. Which of the following would be an incorrect answer?
questions.solution:
Micro RNA 122 is not a marker of acute kidney injury. It is an example of tissue specific miRNA, highly expressed in liver.

Biomarkers of AKI
 Biomarker types    Biomarkers
Functional markers Serum Creatinine, plasma serum cystatin C
Up regulated proteins NGAL, KIM -1, LFAB ,and IL-18
Low molecular weight proteins Urine cystatin C
Enzymes NAG, GGT

Cystatin C is freely filtered by the glomerulus, reabsorbed and catabolised, but not secreted by tubules. Serum cys-c is sensitive serum marker of GFR. It is a stronger predictor than serum creatinine for risk of death and cardiovascular events in older patients.

Neutrophil Gelatinase-Associated Lipocalin (NGAL) is an emerging biomarker in urine and plasma for early prediction of AKI. It is used to know prognosis of AKI in several common clinical conditions.    

Kidney Injury Molecule-1 (KIM-1) is a transmembrane protein that is specifically upregulated in dedifferentiated proximal tubule cells after nephrotoxic AKI. An extracellular domain of KIM-1 is detectable in the urine soon after AKI.

questions.text: All the following statements are true about Meniere’s disease except?

choices.text: Affected individuals have significantly longer endolymph drainage systems
Deterioration of sensorineural hearing loss, typically low frequencies is seen
It is caused by inadequate absorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac
Predisposing anatomic variations develop as early as 3 years of age

questions.solution:
Individuals with Meniere  disease  have  significantly  smaller  and  shorter  endo- lymph  drainage  systems  as  measured  by  the  distance  between  the  posterior  semicircular  canal  and  the  posterior  fossa  on  MRI.

These anatomic variations develop by 3 years of age and may predispose these individuals to later development of Meniere disease. Acute attacks are superimposed on a gradual deterioration in sensorineural hearing in the involved ear, typically in the low frequencies initially.

The underlying pathophysiology of hydrops is controversial, but inadequate absorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac is the prevalent theory.

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is implicated in the autoimmune disease shown below?
questions.solution:
The disease shown in the image is myasthenia gravis. It is an example of type II hypersensitivity.

Type II hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by antibodies directed towards self-antigens- cell surface or extracellular matrix. 

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of privileged communication?

choices.text: In court of law when asked by judge
Examining a government servant on behalf of the government and revealing the illness to the government without patients consent
Informing the authorties without patient's consent, about a tuberculosis patient  who is refusing to leave his teaching job until cured
Giving details of birth, death and communicable disease

questions.solution:
Even when a doctor examines a government servant on behalf of the government, he should not reveal the illness to the government without patients consent. It is against professional secrecy. He is liable to damages for its breech. And it is not an example of privileged communication.

Privileged communication: It is a statement made bonafide upon any subject matter, by a doctor to concerned authority, due to his duty to protect the interests of the community or of the state.

Examples:

  • In court of law: when asked by judge
  • As compulsory duty:every doctor has to give details of birth, death and communicable disease
  • As a social duty –
    • Railway engine colour blind
    • Bus driver being epileptic, drug addict
    • Pilot having refractive errors
    • Hotel waiter with tuberculosis or typhoid
    • Swimming pool user suffering from STD or infectious disease
    • Person suffering from syphilis or AIDS is likely to marry
  • In cases of suspected crime
  • In self interest both in civil and criminal suits by patients
  • In negligent suits when doctor is employed by opposite party to cross examine patient who filed the suit
  • In interest of patient
  • In insursance reports, he can report any disease found

questions.text: Which is the best indicator for short term (2-3 weeks) control of blood glucose?
questions.solution:
Serum fructosamine is the best indicator of blood glucose control in a short period of 2-3 weeks.

Measurement of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) is the standard method for assessing long-term glycemic control. When plasma glucose is consistently elevated, there is an increase in nonenzymatic glycation of hemoglobin; this alteration reflects the glycemic history over the previous 2–3 months, because erythrocytes have an average life span of 120 days (glycemic level in the preceding month contributes about 50% to the HbA1c value). 

Self-monitoring of blood glucose (SMBG) is the standard of care in diabetes management and is used to measure blood sugar daily (usually twice or thrice daily).

questions.text: Which among the following brain tumours, has the worst long term prognosis?
questions.solution:
Glioblastoma multiforme(Grade IV) has the worst long term prognosis (a median survival of roughly 1 year).

Other options:

In case of anaplastic astrocytoma(Grade II) -  2 to 3 years In Pilocytic astrocytomas(Grade I) -  8 years.

Subependymomas are uncommon, benign (Grade 1)tumours which are slow growing and non-invasive. 

Astrocytomas(Graded I to IV) are the most common primary CNS neoplasm. The term often is used to refer to astrocytomas specifically, excluding other glial tumors.

questions.text: The logo given below represents ______________
questions.solution:
The logo given above represents radiation waste.

Other logos:

  • Cytotoxic waste
  • Biohazard

This is an AIIMS pattern MCQ.

All living things are exposed to ionizing radiation from the natural and man-made radiation sources. The doses to the occupational workers shall be kept As Low As Reasonably Achievable (ALARA).

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Lafora’s disease?
questions.solution:
Glucocerebrosidase infusions are not the treatment for Lafora's disease. There is no approved treatment for Lafora body disease.

The mainstay of management is anti-epileptic drugs, valproate in particular; however, other AEDs such as topiramate, ethosuximide, and phenobarbital can be used to control seizures. Most recently, perampanel, a new AMPA receptor antagonist AED, is shown to be effective.

Lafora body disease is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disease and has an adolescent onset. It is associated with polyglucosan intracellular inclusion bodies. It is characterized by: 

  • Progressive myoclonus
  • Epileptic seizures
  • Dementia 
  • Ataxia. 

Diagnosis is by DNA sequencing. Death usually occurs within 10 years of the onset of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections is not related to grievous injury?
questions.solution:
IPC Section 319 defines hurt (not grievous hurt) that includes bodily pain, infirmity, or disease caused to any individual.

Grievous hurt or injury is defined to include injuries such as emasculation, permanent damage to eyesight (either eye), permanent damage to hearing (either ear), damage to any member or joint, destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfigurement of the head or face, fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth, and any hurt that endangers the victim's life or causes them severe bodily pain, thereby impairing their ability to follow their daily routine for a period of 20 days. 

Other options:

  • Section 320 - Defines grievous hurt
  • Section 326 - Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by a dangerous weapon (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Section 331: Causing grievous hurt to extort confession (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine) or to compel restoration of property.

Other IPC sections related to grievous hurt:

  • Sec 322: Voluntary causation of grievous hurt.
  • Sec 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt (imprisonment up to 7 years with fine)
  • Sec 329: Causing grievous hurt to extort property (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 333: Causing hurt to deter public servant from the duty (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 335: Causing grievous hurt on grave or sudden provocations (imprisonment with 4 years + or –fine)
  • Sec 338: Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life/safety of others (imprisonment with 2 years + or –fine)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a normal site of intracranial calcification?
questions.solution:
The fornix is not a normal site of intracranial calcification.

Related Pearl: Sites of normal intracranial calcification

  • Pineal gland
  • Habenular commissure
  • Choroid plexus
  • The dura
  • Ligaments (petroclinoid and interclinoid)
  • Pacchionian bodies
  • Basal ganglia - physiological only in a senile person
  • Pituitary gland
  • Arachnoid granulations

NOTE: The lens (not intracranial) can also be seen as a calcified structure

questions.text: General adaptation syndrome is seen in_________________
questions.solution:
General adaptation syndrome is seen in stress. It is a model of body’s response to stress and consists of three stages: alarm, resistance and exhaustion.

  1. Alarm stage: Upon perceiving a stressor, the body reacts with a fight-or-flight response and the sympathetic nervous system is stimulated as the body’s resources are mobilized to meet the threat or danger.
  2. Resistance stage: The body resists and compensates as the parasympathetic nervous system attempts to return many physiological functions to normal levels while body focuses resources against the stressor and remains on alert.
  3. Exhaustion stage: If the stressor or stressors continue beyond the body’s capacity, the resources become exhausted and the body is susceptible to disease and death.

questions.solution:
The half-life of this drug is 350 minutes.

In first-order kinetics:

Therefore,

t1/2 ~ 350 minutes

  • t1/2 - Plasma half-life

  • CL - Clearance (0.1 L/min)

questions.text: Which one of the following is a muscle splitting incision?
questions.solution:
Lanz incision is an oblique muscle splitting incision used for appendicetomy. It is cosmetically better than the Mcburney’s Grid iron incision.

Rutherford-Morrison’s incision is a oblique muscle cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary.

Chevron (rooftop) incision is a bilateral anterior subcostal incision which provides excellent access to the upper abdomen for total gastrectomy, operations for renovascular hypertension, total oesophagectomy, liver transplantation, extensive hepatic resections, and bilateral adrenalectomy etc.

Kocher’s incision is used for open cholecystectomy.

Pfannenstiel incision is not a muscle cutting incision. Rectus abdominis muscle is not attached to the posterior sheath below the umbilicus and following separation from the anterior sheath, the muscle is retracted laterally.

questions.text: According to WHO, a child is severely malnourished if __________
questions.solution:
According to WHO, a child is severely malnourished if:

  • Symmetrical edema is present
  • Weight/Height is <70% of expected
  • Height/age is <85% of expected

Note: Weight-for-age is not a parameter for WHO classification of malnutrition. It has limited clinical signifcance as it does not diferentiate between wasting and stunting.

WHO classification of malnutrition:

 

Parameter  Moderate malnutrition Severe malnutrition
Symmetrical edema no yes
weight/height(wasting) -2 to -3 S.D(70 to 79% of expected) < -3 S.D (<70%)
Height/age(stunting) -2 to -3 S.D(85 to 89%) < -3 S.D (<85%)

questions.text: A study was done in 1978 in which babies born between 1969 to 1975 were investigated for the effects of electronic fetal monitoring during labor. The number of neonatal deaths was measured. This is an example of which of the following type of study?
questions.solution:
This is an example of a retrospective cohort study since the outcome (neonatal death) has already occurred before the start of the investigation. The investigators went back in time (1969 to 1975) to select the study groups.

Cohort study: It progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not the disease.

  • Prospective/ concurrent cohort study: The outcome has not occurred at the time the investigation begins. It will start in present and continue in the future.
  • Retrospective/ historical cohort study: The outcome has already occurred at the time the investigation begins. The investigation started in the past and continued till the present.
  • Combination of prospective and retrospective cohort study: Outcome has already occurred at the time investigation begins. The investigation is done from the past to the present. And then from the present, it is followed up in the future, looking at the effects of the outcome.

In a case-control study, progression is from effect to cause as an outcome or disease has already occurred. It uses a control group to compare and support the inference.

A nested case-control study is a case-control study nested in a cohort study. Cases of a disease occurring in a defined cohort are identified. Their controls are those who have not developed the disease by the time the disease occurred in the case. They are also taken from the same cohort.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Randomized Controlled Trials

Randomized controlled trials are a type of experimental studies.

Types

  • Clinical trials
  • Preventive trials
  • Risk factor trials
  • Cessation experiments
  • Trial of etiological agents
  • Evaluation of health services

General Design of an RCT

Steps of an RCT

  • Drawing up a protocol
  • Selecting reference and experimental population
  • Randomization
  • Manipulation or intervention
  • Follow-up
  • Assessment of outcome.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the triad of Sandblom?
questions.solution: The triad of Sandblom consists of Obstructive jaundice, Malena, Biliary colic. Hypotension is not a part of the triad.

questions.text: Which of the following hernia is found in fossa of Landzert?
questions.solution:
Mesocolic (paraduodenal) hernia: Mesocolic hernias are unuasual congenital hernias in which the small intestine herniates behind the mesocolon.

  • Left sided paraduodenal hernia is found in fossa of Landzert.
  • Right sided paraduodenal hernia is found in fossa of Kolb.

Other options:

  • Richter hernia: A small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia.
  • Maydl’s hernia/Hernia-en-W/retrograde hernia: Two loops of bowel remain in the sac with the connecting loop inside the abdomen.
  • Mesenteric hernia:  Mesenteric hernias occur when the intes­tine herniates through an abnormal orifice in the mesentery of the small intestine or colon.

questions.text: A mother of a newborn noticed vaginal discharge on her sixth-day postpartum. It was explained that it is normal and called lochia. Arrange the correct order of the appearance of lochia.
questions.solution:
The correct order of appearance of lochia is rubra-serosa-alba.

Lochia refers to the vaginal discharge resulting from the sloughing of decidual tissue in the early puerperal period. 

Name Colour Timings after delivery Contents
Lochia Rubra Red First few days  Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, Vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia Serosa Yellowish/pink After 3 to 4 days WBCs, cervical mucus, micro-organisms
Lochia Alba Pale White After 10th day Decidua, cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterin crystals and fat cells 

The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL and may persist for about 3 weeks.

Malodorous lochia may signify underlying infection. Copious or absent lochia may also indicate infection or lochiometra. The persistence of lochia rubra beyond the normal limit may signify subinvolution or retained bits of the conceptus. Prolonged discharge of lochia alba for more than 3 weeks may signify local genital lesion.

questions.text: An elderly woman lost her husband who suddenly died in a car accident couple of years ago. They had been staying alone for almost a decade with rare visits from her son and grandchildren. About a week after the death she heard his voice clearly talking to her as he would in a routine manner from next room. She went to check but saw nothing. Subsequently she often heard his voice conversing with her and she would also discuss her daily matters with him. This however, provoked anxiety and sadness of mood when she was preoccupied with his thought. She should be treated with_________.
questions.solution:
She should be treated with clomipramine.

In this case scenario:

  • Death of loved one
  • Hearing the voice of deceased
  • Preoccupation with thoughts of the deceased which is leading to anxiety and depression
  • Symptoms>1 year(couple of years)

Hence the diagnosis is pathological grief reaction and psychotic symptoms are secondary to depressive symptoms. So the drug of choice in this patient is antidepressants . Among the following , Clomipramine is the only antidepressant.

If the symptoms would have been less than 1 year(average duration is probably 6 months) ,then diagnosis changes to normal grief and ans can be option b as they normally require no treatment but can take benzodiazepine for short terms.

Note: This is a controversial question taken from a previous AIIMS  paper. The question can be interpreted as : wife discussing her daily matter with her deceased husband is a psychotic symptom which is leading to anxiety and depression.So depressive symptoms are secondary to psychotic symptoms ,the drug of choice changes to antipsychotic i.e. haloperidol.

questions.text: Which of the following shows a U-shaped dose-response curve?
questions.solution:
Vitamins and essential metals show a U-shaped dose-response curve.

At a low dose, adverse effects are observed because there is a deficiency of these nutrients to maintain homeostasis. As dose increases, homeostasis is achieved, and the bottom of the U-shaped dose-response curve is reached. As the dose increases to surpass the amount required to maintain homeostasis, toxicity can ensue.

Thus, adverse effects are seen at both low and high doses. 

Hockey stick-shaped dose-response curve for toxicants that are also metabolic by-products. 

Inverted U-shaped dose-response curve for ligands that downregulate their receptors.

questions.text: Regarding intestinal tuberculosis, which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Treatment is similar in the immunocompromised or nonimmunocompromised
The diagnosis is often confused with ulcerative colitis
The most frequent site of intestinal involvement of M. tuberculosis is the jejunum
Surgical intervention is commonly required for MAC infection

questions.solution:
The treatment of M. tuberculosis is similar in the immunocompromised or nonimmunocompromised host.  The organism is usually responsive to multidrug antimicrobial therapy.

The most frequent site of intestinal involvement of M. tuberculosis is the distal ileum and cecum, with approximately 90% of patients demonstrating disease at this site.

An important differential diagnosis for Ileal tuberculosis is Crohn’s disease. However, cobblestone appearance of the mucosa is a feature seen in Crohn disease that is not seen in TB.

Surgical intervention may be required for intestinal tuberculosis, particularly M. tuberculosis.

Obstruction and fistula formation are the leading indications for surgery; however, with current treatment, most fistulas now respond to medical management.

questions.text: Pantothenate kinase associated neurodegeneration is_______________.
questions.solution:
Pantothenate kinase associated neurodegeneration is Hallervorden-Spatz syndrome.

 Hallervorden-spatz syndrome:

  • Rare autosomal recessive neurogenerative disorder.
  • Neuropathologic examination indicates excessive accumulation of iron containing pigments in the globus pallidus and substantia nigra.
  • MRI shows decreased t2 signal in globus pallidus and substania nigra. It is known as eye of the tiger sign.

questions.text: A pregnant lady presented with cervical lymphednopathy. She was prescribed Spiramycin but was noncompliant. The baby has intracerebral calcification. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The pregnant lady was noncompliant i.e. did not take spiramycin properly ( which is DOC of toxoplasmosis in pregnancy). Hence the baby developed congenital toxoplasmosis with intracerebral calcification.

Lymphadenopathy is classical clinical sign of Toxoplasmosis. Deep cervical lymph node are most commonly affected.

questions.text: Substitution of lysine for glutamic acid residue in the 6th position of the beta-globin gene leads to formation of__________
questions.solution:
• HbC is due to substitution of Lysine for Glutamic acid residue in the 6th position of the beta-globin gene.
  • HbS is due to substitution of Valine for Glutamic acid in the 6th position of the beta-globin gene.
  • Hb Bart is the deletion of all four alpha globin genes. (There are only 2 beta globin genes)
  • HbH is the deletion of three alpha globin genes.

questions.text: Rosenthal fibers are______
questions.solution:
Rosenthal fibers are intracytoplasmic inclusions. It is a reaction of astrocytes to injury. They are thick, elongated, brightly eosinophilic, irregular structures that occur within astrocytic processes and contain two heat shock proteins (alphaB-crystallin and hsp-27) as well as ubiquitin.

It is typically found in regions of long standing gliosis. And is also characterictic of pilocytic astrocytoma. Abundant of it is found in periventricular, perivascular and subpial locations in alexander disease (leucodystrophy associated with mutations in gene GFAP).

questions.text: A patient who previously received anti TB drugs for pulmonary TB for a period of 6 week has presented with confirmed TB findings again. According to RNTCP, this patient should be categorised as___________.

choices.text: Treatment after loss to follow up

questions.solution:
A patient presenting with confirmed TB findings who has previously received anti TB drugs for pulmonary TB for a period of 6weeeks(>1month) should be categorised as Treatment after loss to follow up.

Related Pearl: Classification of TB Patients Based on History of Treatment

New case is defined as a TB patient who had

  • Never taken ATT previously or
  • Taken ATT for < 1 month

Previously treated Case : Patients who have received 1 month or more of Anti TB drugs in the past. These include:

  1. Recurrent TB: A TB patient who had completed course of treatment / declared cured and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case
  2. Treatment after failure: Patients who had been treated for TB and their treatment failed at the end of most recent course of treatment
  3. Treatment after loss to follow up: A TB patient who had been treated > 1 month on ATT and registered as lost to follow up and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case of TB
  4. Other previously treated patients: Patients who had been previously treated but whose outcome is now unknown/undocumented

Transferred in: A TB patient who has been received in a TB unit after having registered in another TB unit for treatment.

questions.text: The anomaly shown in the image given below is mostly associated with ____________
questions.solution:
The anomaly shown in the image is caudal regression which is mostly associated with maternal diabetes.

It is a rare anomaly. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and, to a lesser degree, the lumbar vertebrae, and occurs approximately 200 times more frequently in infant of a diabetic mother than in other infants.

questions.text:
Which among the following best describes sepsis?

SOFA - Sepsis-related Organ Failure Assessment

qSOFA - quick Sepsis-related Organ dysfunction Assessment

LODS - The Logistic Organ Dysfunction System score

SIRS - Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome score

choices.text: Suspected or documented infection with SIRS score ≥ 1
Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score  ≥ 1
Suspected or documented infection with LODS score ≥ 1

questions.solution:
Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2 best describes sepsis among the given options.

Sepsis is defined as, life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection.

To help in recognizing sepsis, Sepsis-3 clinical criteria have been used, which include:

  • Suspected infection  
  • Organ dysfunction which is assessed using the SOFA score - an increase of ≥ 2 points from the baseline of this score 

SOFA score ranges from 0 to 24 points and is divided across 6 organ systems. It includes:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

A simplified version of the SOFA score is known as the qSOFA score (Option C). It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is considered superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thus, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

Other scoring systems for sepsis:

Option A:

Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) is an exaggerated defence response of the body to a noxious stressor to localize and then eliminate the endogenous or exogenous source of the insult. SIRS is diagnosed when two of the following are present:

  • Hyperthermia (>38 Degree Celcius) or Hypothermia (<36 Degree Celcius)
  • Tachypnoea (>20/min) or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) of less than 32 mm Hg
  • Tachycardia (>90/min) 
  • White cell count >12 x 109/litre or <4 x 109/litre or >10% Band forms

 Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection. SIRS score is no longer recommended as is it not specific to infection.

Option D: LODS score is not recommended as it is complex and has too many variables.

questions.text: A patient with a condition related to high environmental temperature was brought to the hospital. Sweating is present in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Sweating is present in all of the given conditions except classic heatstroke.

Heat stroke/thermic fever/heat hyperpyrexia is characterized by a raised rectal temperature of more than 41°C. 

There is a loss of thermoregulatory function and failure of cutaneous circulation and sweating. The predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, old age, lack of acclimatization, and alcoholism.

Heatstroke can be of two types:

  • Classic heatstroke (CHS)is seen in those with chronic diseases that predispose them to heat-related illnesses. 
  • Exertional heat stroke(EHS) is seen in young, previously healthy people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures. T

Patients usually present with a sudden collapse. The skin is dry, flushed, and hot. Sweating is absent in CHS but present in about 50% of cases of EHS. Dry skin in the presence of hyperpyrexia is virtually pathognomonic. Tachypnea (rapid Kussmaul type of breathing), tachycardia, hypotension, and widened pulse pressure are other findings.

CNS dysfunction signs include delirium, coma, and convulsions. Thermal cardiomyopathy and heat-related reversible increase in cardiac biomarker levels are also seen. The ECG may display tachyarrhythmias, nonspecific ST-T wave changes, and heat-related ischemia or infarction. 

Other complications include rhabdomyolysis, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and multiorgan failure.

CLASSIC HEAT STROKE EXERTIONAL HEAT STROKE
Older patients Younger patient
Predisposing health factors/medications Healthy condition
Epidemiology (heat waves) Sporadic cases
Sedentary Exercising
Anhidrosis (possible) Diaphoresis (common)
CNS dysfunction Myocardial/hepatic injury
Oliguria Acute renal failure
Coagulopathy (mild) Disseminated intravascular coagulation
Mild lactic acidosis Marked lactic acidosis
Mild creatinine kinase elevation Rhabdomyolysis
Normoglycemia/Calcaemia Hypoglycemia/Calcemia
Normokalemia Hyperkalemia

Management of heat stroke is as follows:

  • Rapid cooling must be initiated as soon as possible 
  • Continuous monitoring with a rectal thermistor (flexible thermometer)
  • Fluid resuscitation, as determined by the patient's volume status, urine output, and cardiopulmonary function
  • Correction of electrolyte and metabolic abnormalities (hyponatremia and hypoglycemia)
There is no role of antipyretics in the control of environmentally induced hyperthermia. They also exacerbate the complications (acute kidney injury, hepatic failure, DIC).

Hyperthermic anhydrosis / Desert syndrome - The symptoms are similar to those of heat exhaustion. After many days of intense generalised sweating, all areas of the body below the neck abruptly stop sweating, but the face and neck continue to perspire. This is due to the hyperkeratotic plugging of sweat glands causing the functional failure of the sweat gland below the neck. 

Other options:

Options A and B: Heat syncope/ heat prostration/ heat exhaustion refers to collapse without any elevation of body temperature. Thermoregulatory mechanisms and CNS functions are maintained. It is precipitated by muscular exercise and unsuitable clothing following prolonged exposure to heat. There is extreme exhaustion with peripheral vascular collapse with scanty sweating. 

Option D: Heat cramps are painful muscle spasms caused by the loss of water and salt in high temperatures due to profuse sweating.

Related Pearl: Hyperthermic disorders

Hyperthermic disorders Mechanisms
Heat edema Cutaneous vasodilation and pooling of interstitial fluid leads to swelling of hands, feet, and ankles
Heat syncope Vasodilation and volume depletion(from sweating) following exercise or prolonged standing with consequent systemic and cerebral hypotension
Heat cramps Deficiency of sodium, potassium, and water at an intracellular level, leading to intermittent, painful, and involuntary spasmodic contractions of skeletal muscles
Heat exhaustion

Results from prolonged strenuous activity. There is water or salt depletion, but thermoregulatory mechanisms are maintained. Temperature < 40.5° C
Heatstroke

Thermoregulatory mechanisms are lost

Temperature > 40.5° C

questions.text: Which of the following fertility indicator can change with changes in age specific mortality rates?
questions.solution:
Net reproduction rate can change with changes in age specific mortality rates. General fertility rate, total fertiiity rate and gross reproduction rate are not dependent on age specific mortality rate..

Net Reproduction Rate: It is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: A 42 year old male with a past history of a manic episode presents with an illness of 1 month duration with depressed mood, anhedonia and profound psychomotor retardation. The most appropriate management strategy is prescribing a combination of:
questions.solution:
This is acute bipolar depression. Treatment includes mood stabilizer along with antidepressants as using antidepressants alone in depressive episode of bipolar disorder can precipitate manic or hypomanic episode.

Note: Anhendonia is the inability to feel pleasure in normal pleasureable activities.

 

Treatmemt of bipolar disorder: 

1.Treatment of acute episodes:

a.Acute mania
Conditions Preferred drugs
  • Hypomania
  • Mania
  • Mania with dysphoria
  • Mania with psychosis
  • Lithium or valproic
  • Lithium
  • Valporic acid
  • Valproate with olanzapine or risperidone  
b. Acute bipolar depression
Conditions Preferred drugs
  • Mild or moderate depression
  • Severe depression
  • Severe depression with psychosis
  • Lithium or lamot
  • rigine
  • Antidepressant plus lithium
  • Antidepressant plus lithium plus olanzapine
2.Maintenance treatment :  
  • Lithium (drug of choice)
  • Carbamazepine
  • Valproate
3.Treatment of rapid cycling: Valproate (Drug of choice)

questions.text: A pregnant woman with fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain in abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. There is no history of fever. WBC count is 8000cells/ul.  The most likely diagnosis is____________
questions.solution:
In this case, there is severe acute pain abdomen without fever and leucocytosis in a 28 week pregnant woman with fibroid. Hence the most likely diagnosis is torsion of fibroid.

Torsion of sub serous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen but fever and leukocytosis are absent.

Red degeneration of fibroid presents with acute pain abdomen, vomiting. Leukocytosis and raised ESR will be evident.

questions.text: Adding glucose to stored blood ____________.
questions.solution:
Adding glucose to stored blood supports red cell metabolism i.e nutrition.  

Increase of glucose concentration,  had a beneficial effect on blood pH, and on plasma free haemoglobin and K+ concentration. 150% glucose improved the 2,3-DPG maintenance in stored blood.

Blood bank additive have following functions:

  • Sodium chloride provides isotonicity
  • Adenine maintains ATP for red cell viability.
  • Citrate for calcium chelation to prevent clot formation.
  • Phosphate is a buffer to maintain optium PH.
  • Mannitol helps reduce red cell lysis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old is admitted to the ER after being involved in a road traffic accident. Which type of IV cannula would achieve the maximum flow rate to provide fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution:
The orange cannula (14 Gauge) has the maximum flow rate of 270 mL/min.

Tip:

A simple mnemonic to remember these in descending order of their numbering is nature. The mantle zone of the earth is orange, the land is grey, the grass is green, the butterfly on the grass is pink, the sky is blue, and the sun is yellow.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the tubotympanic type of chronic suppurative otitis media?

choices.text: Central perforation in antero-inferior quadrant is commonly seen
Blood stained ear discharge is seen
The discharge is scanty, purulent and foul smelling

questions.solution:
Central perforation in the antero-inferior quadrant of tympanic membrane is commonly seen in tubotympanic type, while marginal perforation in the postero-superior quadrant is commonly seen in atticoantral type of CSOM.

Bloody, scant, foul-smelling ear discharge, ear pain, hearing loss, and tinnitus are often seen in the atticoantral type of CSOM.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with severe pain in the wrist after suffering a fall on an outstretched hand during his morning jog. His X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given features and radiograph are suggestive of volar or reverse Barton’s fracture. Volar-type/reverse Barton's is a fracture-dislocation of the volar rim of the radius. This type is the most common. 

Dislocation of the radiocarpal joint is the hallmark of Barton's fracture. The radiographic findings are the following:

  • Comminuted intraarticular fracture of the distal radius
  • Volar rim maintains a relationship with the carpus and both are displaced proximally
  • Fracture of the radial styloid process with loss of radial inclination

Reverse-type Barton's fracture is similar to Smith’s fracture, but the difference is that the fracture line runs obliquely and extends into the joint surface.

Another type is dorsal Barton's fracture which results due to fracture-dislocation of the dorsal rim of the radius. 

The image below shows the lateral and anterior-posterior view of the dorsal-type of Barton's fracture with dorsal displacement.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: Isoenzymes are____________

choices.text: Physically same forms of different enzymes
Physically distinct forms of same enzyme
Forms of same enzyme that catalyse different reactions
Forms of different enzyme that catalyse same reactions

questions.solution:
Isoenzymes are physically distinct forms of same enzyme but catalyse the same reaction.

Features of isoenzyme:

  • Catalyse same chemical reaction
  • Differ in heat stability eg.heat stable ALP and heat labile ALP.
  • Differ in electrophoretic mobility.eg.CK1 moves faster than CK3.
  • Differ in susceptibility to an inhibitor.
  • Differ in subunits they are made of.eg.LDH-1(H4),LDH-5(M4).
  • Differ in tissue localisation.eg. LDH-1 located in heart and LDH-5 located in muscle.
  • Differ in km value.eg. glucokinase has high km than hexokinase.

questions.text: Healthy thinking suggested by Schneider  includes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Healthy thinking suggested by Schneider doesnt include clarity.

Features of healthy thinking:

  • Constancy : Persistence of completed thought that does not change in content unless and until it is superseded by another consciously derived thought.
  • Organization:Thoughts content  are related to each other and do not blend with each other but are separated in an organized way.
  • Continuity:Thoughts are arranged in order and are in continnuum.

Schneider claimed that individuals with schizophrenia complained of three different disorders of thinking that correspond to these three features of normal thinking.

questions.text: Interpret the ECG shown in the image below
questions.solution:
The above ECG is suggestive of dextrocardia based on the following features.

  • Lead I is inverted with negative P wave, QRS complex & T wave.
  • Reversal of usual pattern of Lead aVR.
  • There is a loss of normal R-wave progression from V1 - V6 with dominant S waves throughout.
  • Right-axis deviation

Differential diagnosis : 

Accidental reversal of right and left arm electrodes may produce similar findings as dextrocardia in the limb leads, but with normal appearances in the precordial leads.

questions.text: A patient with a known case of dermatosis developed new skin lesions at the site of injury on previously healthy skin. Which of the following conditions shows a similar response?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Koebner phenomenon. Psoriasis shows Koebner phenomenon.

Koebner/isomorphic phenomenon refers to the appearance of new skin lesions on healthy skin at the site of cutaneous injury, in the presence of a pre-existing dermatosis. They are typically linear, as they follow the route of the injury.

Koebner phenomenon is diagnosed clinically using the following characteristics:

  • Linear lesions developing at the site of cutaneous injury on a previously healthy skin
  • Lesions have the same clinical and histological features as the underlying dermatosis
  • Lesions are not due to seeding of an infectious agent, allergic reaction or skin breakdown

The exact cause of such a response is unclear. Theories involving T-cell mediated response, involvement of dermis, and microvasculature are considered. Various triggers for Koebner phenomenon have been identified:

  • Trauma: Insect and animal bites, burns including thermal and electric, excoriation, friction, shaving, lacerations, cryotherapy, pressure sores, and orthotics
  • Chemical irritation: Tattoo associated skin reaction, BCG vaccination, tuberculin skin test, hair dye allergy
  • Diseases: Urticaria, inflammatory dermatoses
  • Others: Phototherapy, sunburn, withdrawal of methotrexate therapy

Other features of Koebner phenomenon include:

  • Graded response to trauma: Intensity of response to trauma is unique to each patient and the underlying disease.
    • No Koebner response to injury
    • Abortive Koebner response: Lesions appear, but spontaneously vanish after a few weeks
    • Minimal Koebner response: Lesions develop at the site of trauma
    • Maximal Koebner response: Widespread lesions develop across the entire site of trauma
  • All or nothing response: Patients who develop Koebner phenomenon in response to one type of injury, may develop a similar response due to other types of injuries as well. In case, a patient does not exhibit Koebner phenomenon to one type of injury, it is unlikely that it is exhibited after any other type of injury.
  • Time taken to develop the skin lesions is unique to the patient and the specific dermatosis. It may vary from 3 days to 2 years, normally taking around 10-20 days.

Koebner phenomenon can be classified into:

  • True Koebnerisation: New skin lesions seen with the clinical features mentioned above, as seen in vitiligo, psoriasis and lichen planus.  
  • Pseudo-Koebnerisation: Appearance of similar skin lesions at the site of injury in infective lesions like plane warts and molluscum contagiosum, due to the spread of the infective agent (virus) to the new site by seeding, especially due to scratching.

The image below shows Koebner phenomenon seen in a psoriatic patient at the site of trauma.

Koebner phenomenon is also seen in other diseases like:

  • Erythema multiforme
  • Lichen nidatus
  • Necrobiosis lipodica
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Hailey-Hailey disease
  • Darier disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris

Other phenomena associated with cutaneous trauma are:

  • Reverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of skin lesions after trauma to the area, which is seen in psoriasis after dermabrasion or surgery.
  • Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon: Spontaneous repigmentation is seen in distant patches after autologous skin graft surgery in vitiligo.
  • Wolf's isotopic response/isotopic phenomenon: Emergence of new dermatosis at the site of a previous unrelated dermatosis as seen in granuloma annulare developing at the site of herpes zoster and psoriasis developing at the site of contact dermatitis.
  • Pathergy: Occurance of non-specific papules and pustules secondary to heavy neutrophilic infiltrates after an injection or venipuncture, as seen in pyoderma gangrenosum and Behçet disease.
  • Renbök/inverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of an existing skin condition after the onset of a new dermatosis at the same site, as seen in retention of hair follicles on the psoriatic plaques on the scalp while hair loss was present in unaffected areas of alopecia areata. 

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: A patient with a family history of malignant hyperthermia requires a lipoma excision over his arm. What among the following would be the local anesthetic of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Procaine is the local anesthesia of choice in malignant hyperthermia.

Malignant Hyperthermia is a rare genetic disease. It is a hypermetabolic muscle disease that significantly increases oxygen consumption and carbon dioxide production resulting in hyperthermia and severe lactic acidosis. They occur when succinylcholine and inhaled anesthetics like halothane are used (triggering agents). 

Signs of Malignant Hyperthermia are:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypertension
  • High-colored urine (rhabdomyolysis)

Uses of Local Anesthesia

Topical -  It is used for painless cannulation. EMLA (eutectic mixture of local anesthetic) is commonly used.

Epidural anesthesia - It is commonly used to manage pain during delivery. Ropivacaine is commonly used

Nerve block - The anesthetic agent is injected into a single (minor) or multiple nerves/plexuses (major) to induce anesthesia in a desired part of the body. 

Bier's block (Intravenous regional anesthesia) - Induce anesthesia intravenously in a limb in which the blood supply is reduced using a tourniquet. Prilocaine or lignocaine is commonly used.

Tumescent anesthesia - Used in procedures like liposuction, where large volumes of lignocaine and adrenaline are injected into the subcutaneous plane.

Local Anesthesia is also used to manage postoperative pain and neuropathic pain.

 

 

 

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: An 80-year-old man who is a known smoker presented with complaints of fatigue, flank pain, and bipedal edema. Serum biochemistry showed an increase in liver enzyme values and urine microscopy was suggestive of microscopic hematuria. CT abdomen is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and CT is suggestive of Renal cell carcinoma presenting with Stauffer syndrome.

Stauffer syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome seen in Renal cell carcinoma. It is a non metastatic liver dysfunction mediated via interleukin 6.

Stauffer syndrome is characterised by

  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Raised Alkaline phosphatase
  • Hypergammaglobilinemia
  • Prolonged prothrombin time

questions.text: Which of the following antiglaucoma medications is unsafe in infants?
questions.solution:
The use of brimonidine is unsafe in infants. It is an alpha-2 agonist that can cross the blood-brain barrier. This may result in CNS depression and apnoea in neonates. Therefore it is contraindicated in children less than 2 years.

α2 agonists, through the activation of G-protein coupled receptor activation, inhibit the activity of adenylate cyclase. This reduces cAMP and hence reduces aqueous humor production by ciliary action.

questions.text: Your senior resident uses the following instrument while performing a pap smear test for screening of cervical cancer in a 36-year-old woman. Identify the same.
questions.solution:
The image shows an endocervical brush. It is used to collect samples from the endocervix cervix, especially from deep lesions.

Option A: Cervex brush is ideal for collecting samples for liquid-based cytological studies.

Option C: Ayres spatula is used to collect samples from the ectocervix and the endocervix for cytological studies.

Option D: Aylesbury spatula has a sharper and longer tip than Ayers spatula.

questions.text: Best X- Ray view for orbital blow out fracture is _______________
questions.solution:
Best X-ray view for orbital blow out fracture is Water’s view since the floor of the orbit is seen.

The X-ray finding seen in an orbital blow out fracture is Hanging drop/ teardrop sign. 

Hanging drop/ teardrop sign is characteristic of an orbital blow out fracture which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum.

X-ray views of the orbit:

A. Caldwell's view: It is an occipitofrontal view. Structures seen are:

  • Superior orbital fissure.
  • Greater and lesser wing of the sphenoid.
  • Ethmoid and frontal sinus.
  • The floor of sella.

B. Water's view:

  • Occipitomeatal: Floor of the orbit is seen (important in blow out fractures).
  • Occipitomental: Maxillary sinus and floor of the orbit.

C. Towne’ s view: 

Structures seen:

  • Dorsum sellae of sphenoid bone
  • Inferior orbital fissure

D. Rhese view: For optic foramen.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presented with a painless breast lump of 5 x 5 cm without palpable axillary lymph nodes. A diagnosis of ductal carcinoma in situ was made by trucut biopsy. She underwent surgery with the excision of all tumor tissue with adequate margins. Postoperative HPE shows DCIS with high-grade necrosis with 6mm clearance on margins. Which of the following therapies is needed?
questions.solution:
Post-operative management of a case of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of the breast is based on the Van Nuys prognostic index. In the given clinical scenario, the woman is 61 years old (score 1), the tumor size is 5cm (score 3), the margins are 6mm (score 2), and high-grade necrotic features (score 3) are present. So, the total score is 9. A score of 9 with >5 mm margin requires adjuvant radiotherapy.

The Van Nuys prognostic index for DCIS is given below. A score ranging from 1 (lesions with the best prognosis) to 3 (lesions with the worst prognosis) is given for each of the four prognostic predictors. Total scores range from 4 (least likely to recur) to 12 (most likely to recur).

University of Southern California/Van Nuys Prognostic Index (USC/VNPI)
Parameters Score 1 Score 2 Score 3
Size(mm) ≤15 16-40 >40
Margin(mm) ≥10 1-9 <1
Class Grade 1 or 2 without necrosis Grade 1 or 2 with necrosis Grade 3 with or without necrosis
Age(years) >60 40-60 <40
  • Scores 4-6 and score 7 with ≥3mm margin: Excision alone 
  • Score 7 with <3 mm margin, score 8 with ≥3mm margin, score 9 with ≥5mm margin: Excision with RT
  • Score 8 with <3 mm margin, score 9 with <5 mm margin & score 10-12: Mastectomy

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient with Crohn’s disease has had a disappointing response to glucocorticoids and 5-aminosalicyclic acid (5-ASA) agents. He is interested in steroid-sparing agents. He has no liver or renal disease. You prescribe once-weekly methotrexate injections. In addition to monitoring hepatic function and complete blood count, what other complication of methotrexate therapy do you advice the patient of?
questions.solution:
The patient must be advised regarding possible pneumonitis while on methotrexate therapy.

Methotrexate, azathioprine, cyclosporine, tacrolimus, and anti-tumour necrosis factor(TNF) antibody are reasonable options for patients with Crohn disease, depending on the extent of macroscopic disease. Pneumonitis is a rare but serious complication of methotrexate therapy.

Other options:

  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis is an extraintestinal manifestation of IBD and not a complication of methotrexate therapy.
  • Pancreatitis is an uncommon complication of azathioprine, and IBD patients treated with azathioprine are at four-fold increased risk of developing a lymphoma.
  • Anti-TNF antibody therapy is associated with an increased risk of tuberculosis, disseminated histoplasmosis, and a number of other infections.

questions.text: All of the following signs are seen in keratoconus except__________
questions.solution:
Haab’s striae are tears and breaks in Descemet's membrane seen in Congenital glaucoma (and not keratoconus).  In keratoconus, Vogt's striae are seen.

The signs seen in keratoconus:

  • Direct ophthalmoscopy from a distance of half a meter shows a fairly well-delineated oil droplet reflex
  • Fleischer's ring: Iron deposition on the epithelium
  • Munson’s Sign: V-shaped deformity of the lower lid on downward gaze
  • Scissoring reflex in retinoscopy
  • Prominent corneal nerve due to thinning of the cornea
  • Vogt’s striae:  Vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with depressed mood, weight loss, diarrhea and stomatitis. On examination, there is mild swelling of his right leg and pain is elicited in his calf on dorsiflexion of his ankle. Which of the following statements is not true about his condition?

choices.text: It is associated with MEN - 2 syndrome
Parenteral administration of amino acids results in the disappearance of the skin lesions
A fasting glucagon level higher than 1000 pg/mL is considered diagnostic
Resection is the only curative therapy

questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this clinical scenario is a Glucagonoma, which is associated with MEN – 1 syndrome.

Typical symptoms include “4 D’s”: Diabetes, Dermatitis, Deep vein thrombosis, and Depression.

A fasting glucagon level higher than 1000 pg/mL is considered diagnostic.

The characteristic skin lesion, a necrolytic migrating erythema, is noted in two-thirds of patients. The cause is believed to be severe amino acid deficiency and parenteral administration of amino acids results in the disappearance of the skin lesions.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

questions.text: Identify the staining method used in the electron microscopic image given below.
questions.solution:
The staining method given in the image is osmium staining.

Osmium tetraoxide is used to stain lipids in electron micoscopy.

It dissolves in fats, and is reduced by organic materials to elemental osmium, an easily visible black substance. Osmium is a heavy metal and electron-dense. It will appear opaque and can be visualized in electron microscopy.

questions.text: When the membrane potential decreases from +35 mV to -40 mV, the voltage-gated sodium channels are most likely to be in which state?
questions.solution:
When the membrane potential is decreasing towards the resting potential (becomes more negative), the Na+ channels are most likely to be in their inactivated state (C in the given image).

Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels have two gates— an activation gate near the outside of the channel and an inactivation gate near the inside.

Resting-State (Image A): The membrane potential is initially -70 mv and the activation gate is closed at this stage. This prevents any entry of sodium ions to the interior of the fiber through these sodium channels.

  • Activated State (Image B): When the membrane potential rises from -70 millivolts toward zero, it causes a sudden conformational change in the activation gate, flipping it to the open position. During this activated state, sodium ions can move inward through the channel. 
  • Inactivated State (Image C): The rise in membrane potential toward zero also produces a conformational change that flips the inactivation gate to the closed state. But this is a slower process compared to the opening of the activation gate. Therefore, the inactivation gate closes a few 10,000ths of a second after the sodium channel has opened and sodium ions can no longer move inside. Following this, the membrane potential begins to return toward the resting membrane state, which is the repolarization process.

The inactivation gate will not reopen until the membrane potential returns to or near the original resting membrane potential level. Therefore, the sodium channels can only open after the nerve fiber is repolarized.
